Photo of Cafe Sanuki - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Cafe Sanuki - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Manga on the walls to read

8pfNicR38yJoYwbJ3E12AQ.text: "modern cafeteria concept of traditional Japanese noodle shops"..sounds great on their business card, tastes great when you eat there..  Sanuki Service:  Upbeat friendliness was experienced at every point of contact.  Everyone behind the counter was eager to help you with any questions and the cashier was so friendly.  The crew was quick to clear the table of finished bowls and trays when you were done.  Great positive vibe here, sweet.  Sanuki cuisine: The Carbonara Udon is my #1 here. This is a dish that can go so wrong if the cream and noodles aren't quality, they do it right at Sanuki! The noodles are prepped well and was evident in all the noodle dishes I've sampled.  I added the extra braised house pork belly (because I'm extra) as a mini rice bowl option and I'm glad I did, tasty.   The Curry chicken with rice is flavorful non-udon option. Also, over sized bowls are used to serve the main dishes.  I'm not sure if it has a functional purpose, but it's great for social media posts!  Sanuki Ambiance:  I'm such a fan of the operational  design efficiencies!  1) Immediately upon entry is a glass display case showcasing the popular dishes = gets patrons ready to order once in line  2) Menu on the monitors = Clear display of food options and easy to update on the fly  3) Dedicated FTE/staff to take orders which: notifies kitchen staff and is uploaded to POS (point of sale) system for the cashier.  Most of the staff is in the kitchen getting the orders ready quickly and keeping the quality in check. 4) Self Service Drinks = Keeps staff focused on the food and service in the dining area (clearing tables).  Also that Calpico dispenser is awesome, I started tearing up when I saw it. lol  The huge open dining area is attractively decorated with a Japanese Udon house style with wood everywhere.  There's a long bar for single diners and tables that accommodate parties of 6 and 4. The tables are mobile and can be moved to accommodate even larger parties.  Overall this place is such a win.  The quality of food, service for the price point is incredibly tough to beat.  I'll be back to check out more dishes and get my AYCD Calpico in, but that's another Yelp tale.  Enjoy!

ePzHNE2ihxFRQCzl4ZeZ9g.text: For a restaurant that seems to focus on udon, their udon was mediocre. The texture of the noodles was off, not chewy at all. I got the zaru udon with some tempera. The dipping sauce was a little too salty. I also tried my friend's nabeyaki udon. I liked the broth, but the noodles were still missing the right consistency.  The restaurant was mostly filled when we got there, but wait was not too bad for late lunch on a Saturday. I thought prices were reasonable. Overall very average experience, so probably won't return next time I'm in Vegas.

5Y9audEbKoxm7PkMxsjMCA.text: This place reminds me of Marukame Udon in Waikiki.  It's like a cafeteria, you order in at the front and if your dish is quick and easy, you'll get it right there.  If not, you'll go sit down with a number and the food will be brought out to you.  It wasn't too busy when we came in.    We've been searching for a substitute for Udon Monzo closing down.  This is the closest I would say so far.  But still not as good as Monzo.  We ordered some pork belly steam buns, it was huge!  We didn't think it was that big in size.  We did order two cold udon dishes and katsu curry dish.  For two people, it's a lot of food!  Good thing we got our food out before our last friend showed up to order.  She shared it with us.  Oh, I was excited for their lemonade since I haven't had it for a while, sadly it was super bitter.  I don't know if this is the normal for them or not.  I'll have to it again next time we're in.   Overall the food and service was good.  Noodles are better than some places in town.  We would come back.

YVmSOXUBQYvMShQgad6GLw.text: Great food and spectacular service!! We walked in, not really knowing what to expect. I just knew I had been wanting to try it out. You walk in and there's this giant visual  display of their dishes, encased in glass. Very helpful I might add! It's actually quite stunning! We were waiting for a mintue to see if we would be approached but then realized we were supposed to walk up to the counter to order. Hint! Walk towards the right and they will greet you and help you out! We were greeted by several people behind the counter. All very friendly. I mentioned that it was our first time there and they made a thing about it to the other workers and they all said hello in their own way. The menu is very descriptive, with pictures (also helpful). The despcriptions of the food made them all the more enticing. There were also alacarte items, such as tempura vegetables and some other items I wasn't too familiar with. We both had tempura asparagus and pumpkin. The tempura is under a heat lamp and already precooked. (I would have preferred is fresh but it was still tasty) We ordered the Nabaki Udon and the Yaki Udon. To me The Nabaki Udon has a shrimp flavored broth. It has alot of different textures and flavors going on and I think I preferred that over the Yaki Udon. The Yaki Udon has pork belly and cabbage and it came in this gigantic bowl!!! Make sure to come with an appetite!! There's chopsticks, forks and spoons available in a side station for anyone and self serve beverages.   The fresh lemonade is amazing by the way!!! The decor is really nice and clean and they have little Bhuddas and Anime book collections and other fun stuff. I really liked it in there. The staff is amazing and should not go left unnoticed. One of them came by our table and asked how everything was. She explained that the udon is all made fresh daily in an old school machine. The noodles seem to go for miles!!! Lol Overall, great experience!  We will return!

8CBQcx7QTbG-OwjDEIDsgA.text: Came after the third day of EDC to recover. First thing to note that this is more a cafeteria style place to get food. You order what you want at the counter and they will bring it out to you. One thing I noticed was that the workers were very attentive and nice when I was ordering!   There are a lot of choice of things to get here. I personally got to try the nabiaki udon, mentai cream, beef rice, pork belly bao and a couple of rice rolls. The amount of food you get for the price is great. They give you a lot of food and it tastes pretty good.   The nabiaki is a good way to get a variety of items in your bowl.   The mentai cream was pretty delicious, different from the soup style that udon usually comes with.   The beef rice bowl was good, but nothing too special. It was just like any gyudon I have had in the past.   The pork belly bao was pretty good. I really like how the pork belly was seasoned.   The rice rolls were just OK. The fillings were good, but the rice itself was plain. I wished the rice had some additional taste to it.   If you want good, affordable, nice serving sized foods, this is definitely a place to check out!

3DS5Njk2NyBt_Nu9tjgOQg.text: Yum yum yum yum!!  So delicious, some items were simple and good because they were simple and some items were rich and had complex flavor profile. I myself ordered the kamatama udon. Very simple, udon noodles topped with a imported Japanese egg yolk. You poor fish sauce on top, green onions and panko flakes, comes with a side of udon broth. I would definitely order this again. It was so creamy, simple and filling. The bf ordered a tomato sauce seafood udon. For $9.95 it came with a ton of seafood. xa_czf2HmjOo3-xBBUgG0Q.text: It's okay. The place is modeled after Marukame Udon, where you walk in and choose what you want and the person behind the counter makes your food in seconds. But there's something off about their quality and texture of their udon -- it's a bit mushier. I'll push it up to 4 stars because it's nice to have a Japanese udon spot like this as an option in Vegas when the craving hits. Open area and plenty of room for seating.

4tbfvtKfYbtu9KQ87Iq52Q.text: This was my second time at a "cafeteria" ordering-style Udon restaurant. I like this style of ordering because it makes the service even faster, but a downside is it could be annoying to stand in line during peak hours. We came in with a group of 10 around 2PM on a Sunday and there was no wait!  I ordered the Mentai Creamy Udon and sweet potato tempura on the side. Although I didn't love it as much as Marugame, the udon was yummy and great quality! The tempura was good, and the lemonade/calpico soda fountains were on point (we checked-in on Yelp for a free drink). The prices were also reasonable.  The service was great! As soon as we came in, someone met us at the front to explain how we should order. Most of us got our food right away but for the dishes that took longer to cook, they brought it out to our table. Very nice staff!   Overall great food & service, would recommend!

RePIMVMGISeD8z6bJ0HleA.text: Best sankuki style udon ever. Reasonable prices, fresh, and friendly service. Even tho it's cafeteria style, people are friendly and helpful.

pwELBE7z06Kg5rLUpZz_gQ.text: Cafe Sanuki is reminiscent of the Japanese cafeteria-style restaurants I ate at while in Japan. Grab a tray, give your order, receive your food, pay, and EAT.   FOOD Ontama Udon: This was my first time having a chilled udon bowl and it was absolutely delicious. Smooth udon noodles in a flavorful broth and topped with a poached egg, this was perfection.   Beverages: Their beverage machine was one of the highlights of my visit. There's so many different flavors. Peach Sprite Zero is a dream come True.  Tempura: Slim selections. There was hardly any tempura left when I visited, except for some squash and squid. My squash tempura was unfortunately cold. It didn't look like the trays were going to be refilled anytime soon as the restaurant closes at 3:00pm to prepare for dinner.   I wanted to finish up my meal and experience at Cafe Sanuki with a taiyaki, but I was told that the "machine broke down."   SERVICE Speediness isn't the cafe's forte and I was unimpressed with the ordering experience. It's frustrating having to repeat your order several times, wait for some of the people behind the counter to stop chatting and complete your order so you can move on. Aside from all that, customer service was generally fine.   "PRO TIP" If you're deciding to eat here, I'd suggest coming in as early as possible if you want freshly made side items like onigiri and tempura.

_lOHEG_dDMyj_GDNMjFXHg.text: Loved coming to this place. Great atmosphere, nice employees, good consistent food. I would always get the steak teriyaki which was so packed with flavor and goodness, I'd come back to get it often. The prices are very reasonable too, probably the cheapest in town for such quality food. I loved that the steak teriyaki came with a little side salad that tasted just as good mixed in with everything else. The steak itself was always tender and cut up into small pieces which were easy to eat and delicious. The rice was always perfectly cooked. Whatever sauces they put on the steak is simply delectable.

bYQv5DsOzOwQI7WLvEJfZQ.text: I've been back twice for dinner since the opening.  I was very disappointed. It's not as busy like it was before.  The food quality and taste has gone down.  Kake udon didn't taste that great. Not like I remember.  The tempura was cold and stale. Nothing like eating cold shrimp tempura and Kabocha.  Why not make fresh, hot, tempura when ordered?  The clam udon tasted like water. No flavor. The clams were good. The pork plate was ok.   It saddens me because I really liked this place but I will not be going back to Cafe Sanuki.

r3Py82rTB63-uU5MiP4wUg.text: This is a hidden gem in Vegas and it's so great!!! If you're a fan of mentaiko pasta, they have a great mentaiko udon here! Must try and it's just a short ride from the strip :)! Free drink if you check in on yelp.  It's also very affordable and there is plenty of parking.

WH5HArgVVXwql5Xj29TNCw.text: We went here a few weeks ago because I was craving udon and this place is the only one I've seen that serve Japanese udon in Vegas.   They have a variety of udon to try. I got the curry udon with some tempuras. The udon itself is pretty good - cooked the way I like it. The curry sauce was just okay. I think I'll like it better if it's a little spicier.   My husband got the gyudon with the poached egg. It was actually really good - I would definitely get it again next time. He also got the clam udon - it's pretty simple. Just steamed clam in its broth with udon.   The service was great. There were a lot of workers and they're friendly. There's a lot of parking space at the parking lot. I'll definitely go back again when I crave udon.

Love that they have a great selection of tempuras and onigiri to choose from to pair with your Udon. They also serve Takoyaki and Gyoza. I got the Shoyu Udon Soup which was yummy. photos.caption: Photo of Cafe Sanuki - Las Vegas, NV, United States

CJIV-FA7gFLsG5ZYQKmq7g.text: Delicious & affordable comfort carbs!   At Cafe Sanuki, there is a wealth of varieties that you can find here with udon being their main focus (served both warm and cold). Venue-wise, it was located a small plaza in Spring Mountain, with plenty of parking. We came here on a weekend afternoon and there was a modest line to order our food, but the interior was quite pleasant, it's clean and homey.   For lunch, I ventured for their carbonara Udon. First of all, presentation was absolutely enticing. Plated immaculately served in a giant bowl along with a giant ladle. Needless to say, the portion was humongous. Taste-wise, I thought it was satisfactory - there was a good balance of creaminess and saltiness. The noodle texture, however, could be better, mine was a little over-cooked.   Having our belly full with udon, we can't resists ordering their Beef Bowl Gyudon as well (it just looks so darn good). Perfectly sweet marinated beef and onion on a bed of rice; very filling and delicious  We also had the shrimp tempura and karaage on the side, which was just okay. I had zero complaint for the shrimp, it was sweet, fresh and perfectly crisp. The chicken karaage, on the other hand, was quite stale. Not a big fan.   The service was friendly and I absolutely love the cafeteria concept - where you ordered at the counter, given a number, get your own utensils, condiments, food and drinks. Pricing was very affordable considering the BIG portions and good quality. In short, if you're in the area and curiously starving for udon with an interesting twist. This is a spot worth trying.

Photo of Cafe Sanuki - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Udon carbonara. Yum~

mmsilgJPhCpaATtFD5c9vg.text: Talk about throwback from growing up in the 808. Cafe Sanuki spot that had on bookmark for sometime. At time not many places that were making fresh udon noodles everyday. Where now noodles shops are everywhere in Vegas. Cafe Sanuki personality does make it stand alone from the rest. More cafeteria style concept go around Ushape open kitchen. Not only do u get see make fresh udon noodles. All the magic in the kitchen as bonus.   Throwback part.....Rod will appreciate it?! Shirokiya days all over again. They would have all traditional Japanese style dishes can order fresh (couple different hot stations go to) to order, some done grab whatever ur fancy, or the best ones all (lot of choices bento box) pack meals. The glass display with Japanese decor, pictures, and display of the food. I loved the concept soon as I walked in.  The food I know should gone for the udon. I was more in Katsu Curry Mood. It was good. The Japanese style curry was so on point. The katsu it could have been better. The chicken felt meat was little dry. The breading was great. Once u add the "Da bomb" curry action all good. I got order of the pork belly bao. Not fan. The cabbage slaw combine with the pork belly never worked. It overpowered the pork belly and slaw itself nothing special or stood outlet. The portion size on both dishes were great! Prices are very affordable.   The staff was five stars from everyone interacted with all smiles, friendly, and great!!!

photos.caption: Photo of Cafe Sanuki - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Pork Belly Bao
Photo of Cafe Sanuki - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Katsu Curry

f6mbxQ8QwLYmzxOwH73vVw.text: Q:  Why did the Udon noodles stop drinking? A:  They wanted to be Soba!  Ever since my favorite udon place closed down in Las Vegas, I've been heartbroken! It's been a year since I've had some uni udon and I needed some udon! Sure, we had ramen already on this Vegas trip but there's just something about udon that I can't get enough of. After firing up the Yelp app and scrolling through my bookmarks, we decided to come to Cafe Sanuki.  Looking through their menu was torture because everything sounded good. We ended up getting one onigiri in each flavor to-go, the #12 Mentai Cream Udon, #2 Nabeyaki Udon, and two drinks for unlimited Calpico. I friggin love Calpico.   My dish was the Mentai Cream Udon. Chewy, neutral-flavored, springy udon noodles tossed together with creamy umami-forward mentai cream sauce? I can see why this is the owner's favorite. Different layers and bites of salinity made for an interesting flavor throughout the meal. The Nabeyaki Udon was delicious and comforting with a rich and flavorful kake-based broth. It was perfect for the chilly windy weather. We ended up taking the onigiri home and it lasted fine during the five-hour drive. They also tasted great, seaweed still crispy, the next day. I'll definitely bring a cooler next time.  All in all, while this place can't replace my love for the departed udon place in Vegas, this place was definitely incredibly satisfying. It's clean with ample seating and the staff is seriously so nice! So grab a tray and load it up. You can't go wrong with Cafe Sanuki!

photos.caption: Photo of Cafe Sanuki - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Owner&#39;s favorite: Mentai Cream Udon.
Photo of Cafe Sanuki - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Inside of an onigiri.
Photo of Cafe Sanuki - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Interior. Look how cute those lights are.

QUH_yaCbP-9sC8qvYamhKQ.text: Right in Chinatown, this place is a Japanese restaurant, that reminded of my own time in Japan. From the decor and the super accurate food displays to the cafe style (pay for what you grab). I was definitely taken back, they even have unlimited Calpis! Which is also FREE with CHECK-IN.   Came with a group of friends, we ordered the Gyudon, Mentai Cream Udon, miso garlic pork belly, katsu curry, and shoyu udon! I was so happy they had the mentaiko udon which is like Japanese Mayo and fish eggs, sounds really fishy** but it's really good! Everyone thought it was the best thing there after trying mine. Everything else I would say was just about average hence the 4 stars. Was really disappointed in the miso garlic pork belly. The katsu curry on the other hand was pretty spot on!

photos.caption: Photo of Cafe Sanuki - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Mentai Cream Udon
Photo of Cafe Sanuki - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Gyudon and Miso Garlic Pork Belly

1rp1ALsCdrLPJPnXX2_s_g.text: Think of this as kind of a Japanese cafeteria. They have the traditional glass display with artificial models of many of their dishes. Step inside and find a large menu board to choose from. Order at the first station and then move along to the area where they have tempura, gyoza, and other snacky items ready to go so you can just put them on your tray. Then, pay at the register (get your free drink by checking in) and sit down. Staff will bring your entree to you when it's done.   The interior is wonderfully decorated with Japanese items like books and small crafts. They have an extensive beverage station with a Coca Cola freestyle machine (thank you!!!) and tons of Torani drink syrups along with their signature Sanuki lemonade.   We tried their gyoza which were pretty good but sadly a bit cold even though they seemed to be under a hot lamp on the display counter.   I went for the katsu curry as well. The pork was tender and lightly fried with a hearty curry sauce with carrots and onions. The curry wasn't spicy but was still tasty. We got a few assorted tempura items also which were nicely prepared and not heavy or oily but were a bit on the cold side.   Overall this is a unique and fun way to enjoy some tasty Japanese food!

rspCg-WsJbjVWdZTZ6dKMw.text: Cafe Sanuki a good place for quick bite but don't expect anything fancy from it. The restaurant features self-served style which means you make order, pick out add-on items, pay, grab your own utensils and fill up your own drink.  The staffs are friendly and the place is clean.  Will be back

4-zxV5zKOol6LLxLPJUP0Q.text: I go here when I'm feeling for udon or some of the street foods/Onigiri when the Japanese convenience stores have closed. First time I came here, I tried the beef udon, which personally seemed way too sweet, like they'd put too much sugar in the broth. I had also ordered takoyaki, but it barely had any octopus in it compared to other takoyaki I'd had in town.  I didn't really like it the first time, but I've come back a few times since then, ordering the tonkotsu shoyu udon and the Kake udon. I like both of them a lot, and I order depending on how hungry I'm feeling (the Kake udon feels like a smaller portion but whether or not it really is, I'm not sure). I've also started eating onigiri for the sides, and while they're also smaller than others for sale around town and feel sometimes dry (probably from being put under the heat lamp) they taste fine. Best part of this place is the refills you can get of Calpico!

B-rjThNMM4HH1brLGDm9oA.text: Japanese food at its best. Cafeteria style. As soon as you walk in this restaurant you see a display case of the items on their menu. You get to choose off of the menu and also what's displayed on the left side are a variety of side dishes such as tempura, chicken karaage, Takoyaki, dumplings, Inari and a few others. They also have a lemonade drink station with flavored syrups, calpico, along with other drinks. I ordered the seafood udon tomato cream and Takoyaki (fried octopus balls). It was very delicious! I will be back again to try other items on their menu. The service is great and everyone is very nice. I highly recommend you try this place.

bCnaqiBQY6l8vHizbMvsmA.text: Super delicious and affordable udon noodles. It's self serve tempura and small snacks but you order your noodles and they make it fresh. I had the beef udon and it was flavorful.

xRbaGYNH7l4V4vpw8-6-Fg.text: FREE DRINK WITH YELP CHECK IN.   Mostly good.  I have to start by saying that I am NOT an udon fan. I never cared for it, i find it too chewy and boring. Here, it was good. I still don't care much for it, but we did finish the dishes so there's that!  This food was...heavy. The udon falls in your stomach like an anchor in a deep sea. I think it was mostly due to the Seafood Tomato Cream $9.80. Thick sauce, thick udon and plenty of seafood. Surprisingly i thought it all worked here, very delicious, so plentiful it must be shared.   The next udon dish was the Shoyu Tonkatsu $7.80. Good broth, might've been a tad too salty for me but the broth was clean. The chashu was meh but the egg was good. I am 50-50 on this one on recommendation. Probably leaning on the no.  Pork Belly Bao $2.95 - Not much to say. Lacked a bit in taste and honestly could've gone without it but my gf was hungry so this happened. The pork belly was half fatty half lean which is great. The slaw had no taste but yay the bun was soft. I personally would not get this again.  All in all, I think come only if you're an udon connoisseur or lover. Huge LIKE on the drinks fountain, the Cafe Sanuki pink lemonade was excellent! The calpico also really enjoyable.

JD-Nek_XSXNc9sPUvomo-A.text: Place was nice and clean and people are super nice... the food court style was pretty neat the way you have to other . The prices are cheap for the amount of food served. Tried some noodles and some rice bowl both were really good.   Had a little hiccup about one of our orders that didn't come. 0VauTcBcQDMUnNzqOrnZig.text: Cafe Sanuki is located in Chinatown, a few miles from The Strip. Found in the same plaza as Big Lots and right next door to Dotty's Gaming & Spirits.   My husband and I decided to come by here for a late lunch this past Saturday, around 1:15 pm. It wasn't busy, there were only 2 people ahead of me in line and only a few tables occupied.   If you are newbie to Cafe Sanuki, the set up is cafeteria style. This casual eatery specializes in udon but you can also order rice bowls/ plates, tempura, spam musubi and appetizers. You grab a black tray and then head down the small line. Order at the counter in the middle. And then pay at the end where the register is. From where you order to the register, you can add tempura items that are just sitting out if you wish. But these items may be cold since it is just sitting out and not under a heat lamp. So you can actually ask the staff to make a new one for you if you prefer.  Anyways after you pay, you will be given a pager and your item will be brought out to your table. But if you ordered a simple rice bowl, you may be able to have your item ready for you where you order.   After browsing the menu, we ended up ordering:  Pork Belly Bao,$2.95 prior to tax- Messy but a pretty tasty bao. Great tender meat, pretty flavorful. The shredded carrots and purple lettuce is a nice added touch for texture and crunch. But I do want to mention that the bottom of the bao is a little soggy with the sauce and pork belly.   Salmon Rice Roll, $1.75 prior to tax- I opted for this but wouldn't really recommend it. I probably would get the spam musubi in the future. There is just a small amount of salmon inside and was bland. But I think would make a good snack for later instead of with my meal.   #6 Clam Udon, $8.80 prior to tax- My husband ordered this and it had quite a bit of clam. The soup had a great seafood taste, that was light and not too salty. The udon itself had a great chew and was just perfect. The portion size for one bowl is pretty good for one person.   Mini Curry Bowl, $2.95 prior to tax with any udon order- Unfortunately the pork bowl is no longer available in a mini version, per the employee taking my order. But said that one without meat would be so I decided to just get this. I wanted to have a light lunch since we had plans to eat at a buffet later for dinner. I thought the curry flavor was good and wasn't overpowered by one ingredient. And although the mini bowl looked rather small, it actually filled me up and I was full for a handful of hours (but I am typically a light eater). I think this would make for a good meal for anyone if they add some tempura to this mini bowl to round it out a bit.   Drink, $2.50 prior to tax- Free with Yelp check in! I ended up getting calpico, the sweet and some what tangy drink that you are familiar with at the Asian markets. Only the original flavor is available here and tasted perfect. Free unlimited refills here by the way.  ------------------------------ (Total= $17.81 after tax and Yelp check in offer)  Service was very friendly. The employee taking my order at the counter was nice and made small talk with me as I was trying to decide what I wanted to order. And the girl at the register was friendly. When I told her it was my first time here, she called out "we have a first timer" and the employees all shouted out "first timer", lol. You can tell the employees here have a good time here and generally get along.   Wait time for our food was not long. A little less than 10 minutes and our food was brought over to us by a smiling employee.   The restrooms are in the back. The ladies restroom was clean upon this visit and adequately stocked with the essentials (please note that it is a single toilet in the ladies).   There is free WiFi here and plenty of clean tables.   We really enjoyed our food here and wish to come back here in the future on our next Vegas vacation. There are numerous of udon combinations that I would love to try.

13tnPmxE6Y4lZg6BFbVR0g.text: Perfect place for the udon lovers! Variety of flavors/styles, even an Italian fused with Japanese with a Carbonara Udon! Many would think, udon with carbonara? Does it even mix well together? Well, surprisingly they made this pretty good. Although it was pretty heavy and hearty, the flavors were there.   Nebayaki - Soup not too salty which i liked. Everything was good but the meat was a bit dry and stringy (too many connective tissue, a more tougher brisket kind of cut) so not for the ones who doesn't care for the chewy type of meat cuts.  Seafood tomato cream - this is there best seller and i sure sold to me. Cant go wrong with this one. Teriyaki Steak plate - Not bad but had better on this one.  Pork belly bao - This was juicy but nothing super crazy about but a must try at least once kind of thing.  Rice rolls - definitely a must (snack food) for the road, always for me. Refreshing and not heavy and perfect for the rice & blander food type lovers!!  They have an open drink (sorry non-alcoholic) bar which includes assorted types of iced tea, sodas, hot tea and favorite of all, unlimited calpico!!  Prices a bit on the higher end but not super bad. So will definitely be back whenever im back in town!   Staff are super nice and parking was small but descent.

PwhXm4FHWfi3BaSrBXI2Kw.text: Small portion but the udon was vey good. Reasonable price also. This is self serve market unless you order some of their specialty. They will bring the food out for you.

oZ8XXS04odunpkmSuRmhSA.text: This place was a dream come True!!!!! I came during soft opening and it was so good. They ran out of hand rolls but it's okay because I will definitely be back! They have a cafeteria style set up and serve udon and curry. They also have a tempura station of various vegetables and shrimp. I had a few of the shrimp tempuras and they were killer! Everything was priced extremely reasonably and the seating area is soooo large which is awesome because it accommodates everyone.   I had the bukakke (lol) udon with a soft boiled egg. It was delicious and the broth was simple, but piping hot which I loved.   The whole concept itself is unique, I've never expierenced anything like it. Amazing food, good prices, and superb quality. I love me some Sanuki!!!!

oJVgSarmk9g7176nNttTTA.text: This is one cool cafe! I wanted to eat here ever since my bff told me how the food is so great here. I had the udon with beef, chicken skewers, and the rice and tuna wrapped in seaweed(I forgot what this was called..). I can honestly say that the udon was great! Chicken was good but nothing special. Even the seaweed wrap had the perfect amount of tuna.  The only negative about this cafe is that they do not have any vegan dishes. I want to take my girlfriend here but no vegan dishes! Please consider making vegan udon so I can bring my girlfriend every weekend! :)

tvQFPYU5T7Oi6cVgEdaagA.text: Terrible customer service, udon's cold, and the sides are all pre made! Sides consist of - gyoza, shrimp tempura, tempura asparagus, and takoyaki balls. Since all the sides aren't made fresh, they're really really cold! Also, they gave our order away and didn't tell us until we asked. Only then they began to make our order. We waited an extra 30 min and even though we were the first to get there and order, we were the last to eat and leave! Never going back!

S3Z2Par7y2Jo1r5wdBfiWQ.text: The Skinny: go for the udon, tempura and the lemonade, skip the curry katsu (3.5) service: great for a counter service restaurant (4) value: for the quality and ambience, this place is great (4)  The hubby wanted to come here to try their curry katsu (not sure why as it is more focused on udon) so we came in for lunch.  I had a hard time choosing from all the options. It was exciting watching the noodle maker cooking fresh noodles in the large pot. I ended up getting a bowl of niku udon with a garlic miso pork belly mini bowl which I shared with my toddler. We also bought a few tempura to try (sweet potato, kabocha squash).  We used the Yelp check-in to get a free drink too.  Okay, the niku udon was good solid rendition. The noodles had a nice texture and flavor. The kiddo gobbled up her portion and was quite content. The garlic miso bowl was also quite tasty and would easily recommend.  The tempura batter was light and crisp. It's self service for the dipping sauce at the condiments station.  Their specially blended house-made lemonade was dubbed "baby crack" by the end of the visit. My kid barely came up to breathe as she sucked the delicious concoction through the straw. The rest of the day, all she could talk about was how much she wanted more lemonade. The lemonade is very different from traditional lemonade - it's less acidic and slightly more creamy(?). It's not quite yuzu, and maybe the creaminess may have some coconut overtones to it? It's really hard to pinpoint what it is but it is good.  The only disappointment was the curry katsu. The curry was a little thin and generic tasting while the batter kind of just fell off the pork chop.   As a restaurant, it is pretty great place for kids. The area and high chairs are clean. The restaurant staff is very nice and helpful. They came by and offered my daughter her first taiyaki (she liked this too but not as much as the lemonade). Service is quick and efficient. Only thing is the bathroom does not have a changing table for those with younger children.  For a quick bite, this place is hard to beat at these prices. Add in the friendly staff and ambience, this place warrants return visits. (4).

WAqyJn-EEvVAZ4jq-X1CIQ.text: Delicious and friendly staff. However, several items we wanted to order were not available.

qLU4A80S13IGOk2xO0RiHQ.text: HYPE HYPE HYPE,  If you've been to Mitsuwa plaza or Tokyo Town,  this place is nothing to rave over.  all the poor review is dead on,  noodles overcooked then udon dishes are not the stars of the show.  What pains me the most is the freshly made onigiri photos that are handmade, but if you order it, you get the Asian 7-11 rice balls. So not cool.  I wanted this place to be as good as people rated it but at the end, it's just a buncha kids who never traveled hyping it up.  I say this because on flamingo down the street from Jinya Ramen is oodle of noodle. It's such a corny name but that place has way better udon and their mentiako cream udon is the EXACT SAME PRICE.  This place is just a cafeteria,  they should not be charging restaurant prices.   So why not 1 star?  They are friendly and their business model seems on point.  The food is meh,  some dishes overly seasoned.  Not that it should matter but sadly it does,  no one behind the counter who is cooking is Japanese.

O1J5A9X1fC0PGnZaejLGJQ.text: Nice service and friendly staff. Eat with big bow, which is very funny for a good picture. Food is ok not really delicious. Easy Order and fast.

loCVVQJdZOMN3GWdFyui5Q.text: One of my favorite cafe to go in. Good quality food and their area is always clean and it would be a good place for a fine dinning

lLis3XzXXm5ntiOgwO2_TA.text: The tempura was soggy and cold. No flavor. The pork in the udon was dry and the broth had no flavor. The spicy miso pork bowl was good but was the only dish that was. When I first walked in the place was empty, that should've been my warning. The staff was really friendly, though.

EcRrtM5CpfAJFY8do2LCBw.text: Amazing tasting food. Great service.  They also have a discount for military/civil service. Will definitely be coming back!

9C81S9fMvJJiRg5Qhat9Xw.text: The udon is good! The staff are friendly and the restaurant is clean! I wish it was closer, but it's worth the drive! Their #2 is my favorite. I forgot what it's called, but it has the shrimp tempura in it. Huge portion too! Also, they have a refillable Calpico! Never seen that before since Calpico is expensive in other restaurants. Their lemonade is perfect! Not too sweet!

J89vJMByLu3ik9-6mpNaTA.text: Yes, this place is the spot.  The fast casual approach to udon. All of the noodles are made in house so you know it's fresh. There is an open kitchen where you can see everything being made. The system is really easy to understand when ordering. The udon soups are really great. The noodles are amazing, and the broths they use are very good. They even have really creative udon dishes like carbonara and seafood tomato.  Cafe Sanuki also has tempura. They were light and crispy. If you don't want udon, you can get a rice bowl. I tried the pork belly bowl, it was quite good. Hopefully they will carry oden soon, that stuff is awesome.   The service was awesome, everyone was super friendly and eagar to assist.  I will definitely be back, this is a great idea, and the food is quick and really well done.

grkV0iQh6_RYQlHA8qON1Q.text: Came here for dinner with some friends. The interior is clean and well organized. There is a display of all the food they offer as soon as you walk in. For the price, the food was not as good as I was expecting. The mini curry and rice tasted mediocre at best. The tempura offerings were slim at the time we went. However, there were not a lot of people in the restaurant which makes me question why they were not restocking the tempura for the next rush of people. The carbonara udon was served in an overly big bowl which was interesting presentation wise but didn't help much with taste. My girlfriend and I have had udon carbonara before and Cafe Sanuki's take on it has much to improve on. The sauce stuck to the noodles which made the dish dry after mixing and not as creamy as when the dish first arrived. There was an overabundance of cheese mixed in and as a topping which overpowered every other flavor. The amount of cheese that was served with this dish made it hard to eat. We finished all of it solely because we didn't want our money to go to waste. The only thing preventing this review from going down to two stars is the service. The staff was kind and friendly which made ordering a breeze. Most likely will not be coming back here.

photos.caption: Photo of Cafe Sanuki - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Udon Carbonara
Photo of Cafe Sanuki - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Mine curry and rice bowl with tempura shrimp and papaya

8hxpsrDAS7TBgBWmyxvF1A.text: Honestly, this place is okay but i do like that it is quick and fast. If your trying to eat some noodles and want something really quick then this is the place for you

_d1y5MUXOHHJfjNuBn-c_A.text: I love this place and I always make sure to stop by whenever I come to Vegas with my friends or family. It's a cheap eat break from all of the overpriced food on the strip and the portions are very generous. I always get the Niku beef udon and a mini braised pork belly bowl. The seasoned beef in the udon is delicious and the noodles are always fat and chewy. The broth is so good and you can always add spice or flavor with the condiments that they have out. The mini braised pork belly is so so good and so worth the price of $4 - they give you 3 fat slices of marinated pork belly with rice. Also if you check in on yelp you get a free drink! They have lots of drink options, including that customizable drink machine as well as iced teas and Calpico. I love getting their peach cream soda. Can't say enough about this place - try making a stop if you're visiting Vegas, it's only about a 10 minute drive from the Strip!

hOnwbZjdoPETSPi1C0NlTQ.text: I give this place a 3.5 stars. If you are looking for something quick and wanting hot soup this place has it all! Cafeteria style! They are quick on most of their dishes! Very clean and staff are very friendly!   All items i I order came out promptly and was very hot and fresh! Come try it out!!!!

2kWd4ToCxMmDb6WogcerqA.text: Okay, this place is amazing!   I love udon, but I haven't really found anywhere with great udon in Vegas. Until now! I went with my bestie to check Sanuki out after Yelp's suggestion and I'm so glad I did.   The atmosphere is cool. It's cafeteria style so you grab a tray and tell them what you want, then seat yourself. I had the kitsune udon and it was delicious! Their house lemonade is really good, too.  Staff was great and very helpful! I'm already planning my next visit!

bcdnA5eszfW-M-NW4E08ng.text: Amazing fresh noodles, salads are awesome the Lemonade is the best in Las Vegas. Service is 10+.  We are here all the time.

3m5Lqrvh-lvJNn1r0YjwBg.text: Loved the service and the food here! It was our first visit to Cafe Sanuki and Macro quickly greeted us at the door to explain the cafeteria-style restaurant protocol. If I'm in Vegas, this would be my go-to place for comfort food!

Nji9TrQK3ED5vyb34-pYQA.text: It was my third time eating at Cafe Sanuki today, and this time I had brought my family with me. We had ordered our food and sat down. Half of us had our food ready and the other half had to wait for their food to finish up. 10 minutes into the wait we start eating because we didn't want the food to get cold. We tell our family to ask about the food a couple minutes later to find out our food was given away to the wrong family. Upset and disappointed, we were told to wait a little longer for a fresh plate to be made. 3 minutes later, the rest of the food arrived. Truthfully, our appetites were crushed. Half of the family's meal was already done, and the other half of us barely started eating. It was an upsetting experience, but only to be fixed by their employee Jasmine. Jasmine, you are the reason we will continue to eat there. Your service and understanding of the situation is so caring and my family deeply appreciates it. Thank you so much for creating a resolution to the problem. Jasmine you are 5 stars!! Thank you so much

iaVumlOOqJAge2HuU-VF6A.text: This cafe goes into to such detail from start to end and as a former Data Analyst and software manager, I appreciate the well thought out detail. When you first walk in, there is a showcase of plastic food showing you the scale of  what you will be eating.  For the visually inclined this is a dream come True. The details, the details! The menu items are all in pictures with the name and a corresponding number. Just in case you mutilate the pronunciation, I am not naming names here, I am just saying! The ordering process is simple and has the efficiency of a well managed school cafeteria. You grab a tray, place your order by number or well spoken food item name and receive your food. Then you move along, see if you want to pick up a little extras and then pay for your food as well as order your drink.  I wanted a rice dish but I also wanted the freshly made udon, so I ordered both- problem solved. For my rice dish, I ordered the #19 the Curry Rice with Pork Katsu and the #5 Kamaage Udon. The Kamaage Udon comes straight from the cauldron of noodles so it is saltier and comes with dipping sauces. So the Kamaage Udon comes in a bucket, I am not joking. A big bucket of noodles, that is so my thing The noodles were fresh and simple, you could taste the purity of the noodles without the distraction of toppings.  The Curry Rice with Katsu was quite alright. The rice was rice and the katsu was a generous size. It was crispy and tender, very good! The curry, I think it was good. I mean I ate it. For the price of $7.45 I will not complain but it was a bit generic but it could also be my taste buds.   Everyone who worked at this new Cafe were top-notch kind and helpful. Definitely a place that I will come back to with all of it's details! All in all, the new Cafe Saunuki is pretty solid with food for the prices they charge.

photos.caption: Photo of Cafe Sanuki - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Tempura
Photo of Cafe Sanuki - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Niku Udon
Photo of Cafe Sanuki - Las Vegas, NV, United States. #5 Kamaage udon

gG_yOeHapjLYAUFuLvTiIw.text: As soon as you walk into Cafe Sanuki, you'll be drooling with all the realistic wax food displays of their menu! The cafeteria style, Japanese dining is a unique casual way to impress anyone especially when your udon noodle is made in house! The amazing food displays are "actual" size versions of what you'll be stuffing your face into! And the BEST part? Entire menu is under $10! They have a wide variety of side dishes (tempura , rice rolls and oden). Check in on Yelp to get your FREE drink!  The super friendly staff eagerly greets you and recommends their most well liked dishes such as the seafood tomato cream, yaki udon or kamatama udon. I ordered the seafood tomato cream and it was delicious! The tomato sauce, cream, and seafood blended well together. The consistency was neither too creamy nor watered down. The udon was cooked perfectly without being too chewy. And wow, $9.95 is definitely a bargain for the generous portions of shrimp, squid, mussels, and fish they provide.  The owner took some time to chat with us. He stated the soft boiled eggs they use are shipped direct from Japan! All ingredients are fresh. In fact they do not have any freezers in the kitchen. They do not use MSG or other artificial flavors in their dishes. They have a self serve bar for your warm tempura sauce and drinks where you have an option to pump your own Torani syrups with all kinds of flavors. The open and airy dining area gives you a welcoming atmosphere. I can't wait to come back and try their rice bowls of goodness!

4Pk99GYCt601bqGKLzkUjQ.text: Love the idea and glad that a quick udon place opened up in Vegas. Fast stop for lunch breaks and cheap prices... cheaper than most other udon places around us.   Cafeteria-style where you choose your udon or rice bowls, then pick out your tempuras and oden (fish cakes).  Large portions sure to leave you full.   Try the creamy lemonade! Very different from anything I've had.   They close between lunch and dinner to prepare fresh noodles.   Not all onigiri options were available, even though they were advertised, such as the plum, which I was badly craving! That was a bummer.   Don't expect the best quality udon, but expect it to be yummy, fast, & cheap- just what I need most times!

S-t370Nl_Vp6wOAeCgL8zw.text: This is as good as it gets. Upon coming here, you can notice that it is very similar to an authentic udon bar found in Japan (as said by my boyfriend, who has been to many udon places in Japan). When you come in, you see a display of plastic udon bowls, giving an example of what to expect. It's similar to a buffet line; you grab a tray and tell the chefs what you want. After you grab your udon or rice bowl, you are lead to a line of 8-10 different types of tempura. You grab a plate and get as many or as little tempura pieces as you want. At the very end of the line, you end up at the cash register and pay for your food.   Now to the food. The food here is AMAZING. The udon was clearly fresh and had a good bite to it. The broth was tasty and not overpowering. The beef pieces were thinly sliced and tender. The tempura were all crispy and the veggies used for them (as I had the pumpkin and sweet potato) were lightly seasoned and delicious. The surprising part of the meal was how delicious their lemonade was! It's sweet but not too sweet while having a slight tartness to it. In addition, it also had a hint of the lemon rind in the drink.   If you really enjoy your udon, do yourself a favor and try this authentic Japanese place out.

0CklFPnyxdqjbuppqtxnKA.text: We came here on a Tuesday during lunchtime, and it wasn't too crowded so service was really fast! Basically you order cafeteria style: you bring a tray with you, and the employee will ask you what style of udon you want. They'll then prepare the udon for you on the spot, and once you grab your bowl you can grab an extra toppings like tempura shrimp.  Drinks are self serve, and they even have CALPICO on self serve!!! AHH that made me a lil' excited!   Anyways, food was solid, service was fast, and I wish they had this back where I came from so I could savor it more.

zjCffYv80quUYrldBUAhwQ.text: Cafeteria style service. I totally enjoyed the Beef Udon. So much so, I went for a second serving. Be Sure to check hours. Cafe Saluki closes from about 2:30 to 5 to give employees a lunch break! Prices are god too though, so bring a date or the family!

WTCGGQzysnYergXMj3abiQ.text: Cafe Sanuki was the newest addition to the many udon places that were popping up in town. My review was based on the their soft grand opening.   Their make their udon fresh from scratch and you can watch their action from the glass while you order your food.   First, you waited in line to pick your udon/ rice bowl. They have over twenty udon variety from kake, bukake, carbonara, clam, tomato based, etc. They also have rice curry bowls as side order or main dish (BIG bowl).   Second, you pick your sides: shrimp tempura, fish cakes and vegetable tempuras, spam musubi (yes they have it too), salmon or spicy tuna wrap, etc.  Last, you pick your drinks. Their lemonade is fresh squeezed and it's pretty good. They also have bottomless specialty brewed tea by Harney and Sons, peach, tropical green, etc. If you like sweet, they have syrups with many different flavors to add to your tea.  I tried their tropical green and it's very refreshing! If you check-in on Yelp, drink is on the house.   I tried their Kitsune Udon with side of shrimp and vegetables tempura. I liked it, udon was perfect, chewy and not soggy. My kake udon soup was also delicious. I also tried their Carbonara and Yaki udon and they were delightful. The bowl for Carbonara or Yaki udon were HUGE, bigger than my head.   Today is my second visit and will come back again with friends and families.

zPVmEvB4jdOOymVgxs_JuA.text: It's only the soft-opening for this restaurant and I was already impressed which doesn't always happen. My friends and I went here for a late lunch after the gym. We had our names on the guest list but there was still at least a 30-minute wait. Normally, I'd be raging from being hangry but something told me it'll be worth the wait.  They started running out of food but what I had planned on eating were still available. Yay! Despite the madness, I can't say enough good things about the owner, Henry and the kitchen staff - they were proud of their product and handled pressure with such amazing positivity, calmness and grace. They were in the flow.   We tried a few things from the menu and we can't wait until they're officially in full operation. I'm especially excited to try their Taiyaki in the future as the ones available in this town have been major letdowns.  Carbonara Udon: This has got to be my go-to udon. The noodles has the perfect texture. The sauce to noodle ratio was spot on. What makes their version stand out is that they use small pieces of pork belly instead of thin slices of bacon. 5/5  Niku Udon: Noods in a hot beefy broth worthy of a big loud slurrrrrppp!!! #ilovemesomemeat 5/5  Tempura: They have a nice variety of breaded, deep-fried artery-clogging goodness: Shrimp, Chicken, Fish Cake, sweet potato, etc. 5/5  Miso Garlic Pork Belly Rice: Thinly sliced pork belly on a bowl of rice. The miso garlic juices mixed with the fatty pork should be enough to get you excited. 5/5  Lemonade: I'd typically say "when life gives you lemons, hope they're Lululemon"...this has got to be the first time I've ever liked lemonade by itself. I've given lemonade way too many chances - it's either too damn tart or diabetes-inducing sweet. Theirs was just right. Henry has every right to be proud of his version of lemonade. I was so excited to get my refill on but they were out! I wish I could do more than 5/5 but that's just a wrong rating system so, yeah, I'd settle with 5/5  My other friends tried the curry udon but we weren't about sharing today. As soon as we got our food, it was every man for himself on don't-talk-to-me-I'm-eating mode.  Henry was doing his rounds when they've pretty much sold out on everything. He was apologetic but honestly, there's nothing to be sorry for. Service, food, lemonade, price...just can't be beat! I've found my new favorite udon place.

z60wasUzcRbrN4-b-odeBw.text: UPDATED.. 2nd Review  So I couldn't help myself and went back 2 more times. Who could pass up their 30% off pre grand opening special!?! Not me lol   Service was good as usual. Everyone was very friendly and attentive. There was always someone running back and forth to help clear the tables and wipe them down for new customers to sit and eat. If I were to leave a suggestion it would be to have a place for us customers to help put our own dishes and throw our trash away since it is more of a self serve restaurant. I'm sure that would help the workers when the lunch and dinner rush comes through. (IKEA has these covered stalls for us to put our dirty trays with dishes in ..maybe that is something useful that may be added to this lovely place)   Kamatama Udon - Very good! Talk about egg porn! Udon is served hot with a raw yolk on top from eggs that are imported from Japan. Chef said these were special eggs from vegetarian fed chickens. Broth/Sauce is served on the side for you to pour over your Udon. Break that yolk and let it ooze all over Udon. Enjoy!  Carbonara Udon - Good. Nice and creamy with chunks of pork belly in it. Pork belly was a little hard and chewy for my taste tho   Curry Udon / Rice Bowl - Good. Flavorful but nothing out of the ordinary. Curry taste like the one in the yellow golden box you make at home.   Miso Garlic Pork Belly Bowl - Very yummy. I love how super garlicky it is. Pork belly is sliced thin and packed with flavor topped with pickled ginger  Of course we ordered the Seafood Tomato Cream & Mentai Udon again. It was as delicious as the first time.   I posted A LOT of pictures of everything we ordered and of the restaurant. If you can't see it with my post here go find them lol Everything looks and tastes delicious. You will not be disappointed.   ...Until next time. Can't wait to try the rest of what we missed on our return trips = )

aPkoxAzkAfgtndmZkBpYQw.text: Yum!   I like the set up of this restaurant.   It actually reminded me a little of some places I've been to in Japan.   I tried the curry and it was pretty darn good.      The pricing is very affordable.   Except for the drinks.   Please take advantage of that yelp check in and get a free drink instead of spending $3 for a soda!   However, I was pretty impressed with the soda bar and all of the amazing concoctions you can create.  Overall, I can't wait to come back and try even more items here.   Yum yum yum

VyCEG9QEXXfAHgDaDrqWbw.text: This place makes you miss Monzo Marugame udon real bad. I was excited to take my parents based on reviews but the noodles were not impressive and the dashi was even more lacking. No amount of topping add ons can camouflage the weak foundation of the dishes.

Cp9e9wyplsNK3LmaD6YVnQ.text: Disclaimer:  Attended the soft opening as one of the Facebook Pre-Opening RSVP Invited Guests on 11/14/2017.  With the Yelp check-in for a complimentary beverage, everything on this visit was comped (including my second bowl of Mentai Cream Udon)  ---------- Personal pet peeve rant: Please do not pronounce UDON like Ming Tsai (for an Asian guy that lived and worked in Japan before becoming a TV chef, it is disrespectful to purposely mispronounce a common Japanese noodle dish that he probably ate numerous times after work.  He is not some guy that might have lived their entire life having never traveled more than 30 miles in any one direction on a farm in Ohio. Udon is not pronounced U-Don. Don't trust the pronunciation provided by the US-based search engines either.  Search Youtube for " pronounciation" for the Japanese pronunciation. Or just ask the staff that works at Cafe Sanuki. ----------  The display of life like menu items made of plastic in the glass display definitely reminded me of the Japanese restaurants my parents took me to when I was growing up in Taiwan and visited on vacations in Japan, S.Korea and even Thailand.  It is not as common nowadays, especially in Nevada, probably due to the cost of these boarder line works of art. But having a visual representation of what you can expect to receive before ordering is nearly priceless. Plus photos, even really really good ones, can only do so much.  Bonus points for that authenticity feel!  So after I verified that I was at the right address, by stepping back into the parking lot to double check the signage on the outside of the building, I was immediately greeted by two lovely hostesses with a clipboard to check in.  I was given a laminated voucher to redeem at the cashier, and suggested to check out the fresh udon being prepared by a machine right on the other side of the glass partition.  The machine is a sheeter, that rolls the dough into the desired thickness, and then feed through the machine to be cut into individual thick strips of udon noodles.  After it is cut, the udon is dusted with some type of flour (guessing wheat flour) to keep it from sticking together, and toss into boiling water to cook for just a brief period of time.  Very simple process.  The tricky part is deciding what to order in this cafeteria-style udon-bar restaurant. Just looking at their menu, they appear to have at least 16 Udon preparations to satisfy your need for udon noods. Plus 4 options of Rice Bowls (Options: Beef, Curry, Chicken & Egg, and Miso Garlic Pork Belly in regular and mini size options). After placing your udon orders, there are also tempura-fried appetizers that can be selected to compliment your udon entree.  Plus they have 8 different Onigiri (Japanese Rice Balls with different fillings: Spicy Tuna, Tuna Mayo, Salmon, Spam, Mentai, Plum, Kunbu, and Inari), and in the near future Oden selections and Taiyaki (a type of dessert in the shape of a baked fish (sea bream) cake with traditionally filled with Japanese red bean paste filling.  What I ended up ordering are #11 Seafood Tomato Cream and #12 Mentai Cream Udon.  Both of these udon entrees are served in oversized bowls (large enough to fit probably the Costco pack of 2 watermelons or a basketball), which then made the udon portions look deceptively tiny. Plus one of the hostess also asked if I wanted to try a mini Rice Bowl, which I could not refused. And while waiting to get to the cashier, I also picked up a single tempura-fried shrimp (pretty good and the shrimp is not the tiny pinky-sized shrimps often served at the lower-end Japanese or AYCE sushi restaurants) on a tray next to the other tempura-fried appetizers and Japanese "fritters" often served on the side to compliment the udon noodles.  Overall, I thought the price range is reasonable ($5.50 to $9.95), even without the soft opening 30% off discount, and the selection of udon noodles toppings and preparation are pretty extensive.  Plus there is the option to serve some of the udon entrees cold instead of hot, just like in Japan and numerous iconic dishes from around the globe during the summer or winter (e.g., Vichyssoise, aka Potato Leek Soup).  The biggest appeal, besides the convenient location (Decatur and Spring Mountain), is that it is a fast, relatively healthy meal on a short lunch break or for dinner after a long day at work.  Also they have one of those fancy Coke Freestyle Soda Machines with the touch sensitive monitor that you can navigate to dispense up to 144 different beverages. Plus they also have 5 flavors of fresh brew Harney & Sons fruit teas and 8 different syrups to further customize your drinks.  But I totally recommend not trying any of that, especially the sodas, until you have tried Cafe Sanuki's House Blend Lemonade (it is not too sweet, have a pleasant citrus note that I can not quite place).  Give them a try, before Cafe Sanuki gets too popular and the wait is long.  4 stars!

photos.caption: Photo of Cafe Sanuki - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Udon noodle machine.

mDORnXCWKRHA3HXii_iOyA.text: Cafe Sanuki is by far my favorite ramen spot ever.  I normally get the Shoyu Pork.  I have also eaten the yaki udon.  The portion size for the udon noodles is just enough to fill me up and I have a healthy appetite.  The yaki udon is huge and you will definitely have left overs.  It can definitely feed two people easily.  I have been to many ramen and Japanese spots and nothing compares to the way they season the pork.  I will never eat at another ramen spot again.  I have visited several and I keep coming back.  The broth is amazing and so is the pork.  Its marinated just right.  I do highly recommend the egg in tempura. It's just right. The egg just melts right in your mouth.   When you first walk in they have visual plates of what the food items look like.  I am a visual person and love to see what the items I'm ordering look like. It's different to see it on a picture in a menu as opposed to right in front of you made of plastic. There menu is set up on screens kind of like a cafeteria style restaurant and they cook you what you want right then and there.  The workers will come and deliver your food directly to you once its ready.  Also if you check in on yelp you can receive a free drink.  The staff is super friendly, and they also take your tray and food when you are done eating.  Even before you can even stand up to return the trays to the trash area.  They are really on top of their game there.  The restaurant is clean, and the wait time to get the food for it to be fresh is extremely fresh.  I HIGHLY RECOMMEND this restaurant..  I will never get my noodles from anywhere else.

A5H9PVpicI42KL-yEbu54Q.text: This place is so weird.   Pros:  - Nabeyaki udon was HUGE and had great flavor. Definitely not traditional but it was really good nonetheless. - The lemonade was yummy.  Cons: - The lady at the register was kind of rude and was wearing a house arrest bracelet. Awkward.  - The tempura is pre-fried and just sits under a warming which doesn't keep it very warm. Mine was cold by the time I paid, sat down and started eating.  Not really sure why the reviews are so high. Maybe I caught it on an off day...

YxP9Fg-uki0AubSExJEspg.text: Cafe Sanuki is a restaurant on our regular rotation. It's a cafeteria style set up where you grab a tray, tell the kitchen your order (sometimes it's ready in a minute), peruse the hot foods readily available and pay.  Sometimes they give you a number for your table and they will bring the food out to you.  When you are done eating, there's an area for you to return your trays and bring your dirty dishes.  We went during their soft opening and found a hair. They fixed it right away and addressed it.  So I appreciated that it wasn't overlooked. At one point, we dropped our bowl on the floor and the server nearby said she would get a us a new one.  She brought over a new bowl but our food was on the floor.  Nonetheless, they have since taken effort to gain our business and we do go back.    It's a bit challenging to maneuver the trays when you are trying to corral the kids, but we manage.  Sometimes they do offer to help us bring the trays to the table if they see you are struggling and they have the extra hands available.  The kids particularly enjoy the Seafood Tomato Cream dish. We went this past weekend and had the Vegetarian Tomato Basil with cream added since the kids didn't want the seafood in it.  That was well liked again.  The Husband and I usually bounce around the Soup Udon menu - Cold, Warm, and Hot.  We've tried the Niku Beef Udon, the Shoyu Pork, the Kake Udon, the Ontama Udon, the Zuru Udon, the Kamaage Udon, and probably a few others.  We've also had the Katsu Curry Rice, the Braise Pork Belly, the Beef Bowl Gyudon, various tempura, and the Pork Belly Bao.  There hasn't been any dish we haven't like, so that's a good thing.  Sometimes they have FB discounts or a free drink with Yelp check-in.  We particularly love the bottomless Cafe Sanuki house blend lemonade and the Calpico.  You can also register on Clover for more perks.  Overall, it's nice to have Cafe Sanuki in our rotation for a casual lunch.

35oW6FG_qLdlGNi8eVd0Qw.text: I've been wanting to check this place out and I finally got a chance. I ordered the Beef Niku Udon and it was descent. The broth was too salty for my liking and the noodles were a little bit too chewy. The bowl just didn't hit the right notes for me or maybe I should had try a different udon bowl instead of the beef niku.  The fried tempura egg was good and it was perfectly cooked.   The place was very nice and clean. A lot of tables and the decor was very welcoming. Staff members were all nice and provided excellent service.

pqOaOlej1HqvuZ7XbdvI-Q.text: Wow... this place is totally legit when it comes to the freshly made udon and Japanese cafeteria feel.  I've only seen one other place in my travels that has come close to an udon shop in Japan, and that was in Hawaii.    This is a must joint if you're into udon!  They have multiple flavors and variations depending on your mood.  And if that's not your thing, you can enjoy some other nice rice dishes too.  What also makes this place an over the top udon joint, is there all you can drink Calipico soft drink well along with other flavors.    Can't wait to go back and try the other dishes!

ugDI-9TKjDe8LJCqmIu4dA.text: Visited with some friends that we actually consider family!  We came to Cafe Sanuki on their suggestion!  What a find!  These folks know their UDON!  I love me any kind of noodles, but Cafe Sanuki specialized in soup udon, cold & warm udon, and saute udon dishes.  Even on a hot day the udon hit the spot!  They also do different Japanese bowls/plates, as well as appetizers like tempura and rice rolls!  Like musubi, but fancier!  The fam & I tried:  -Kake Udon (with an extra serving of udon added) -Katsu Curry Rice -Salmon Rice Roll -Tuna Mayo Rice Roll  Tasty, casual restaurant fare!  The Kake Udon was nice & hot, broth was light but had a very clean seaweed flavor.  So easy to eat an entire bowl!  The Katsu Curry Rice was good too, pork tonkatsu was friend perfectly and still juicy...and I have no problem with Japanese-style curry!  Great accompaniment with the tonkatsu and lots of rice!  My only thing was I wish there was a few more veggie chunks in the curry.  Still was good eats though!  The rice rolls were pretty basic but still yummy in the cute little packages.  They were light on flavor but after a dash of some soy sauce they were back up to par!  I really liked the Tuna Mayo one.  We'll be back for some easy dining at Cafe Sanuki!  The food was good, the prices were reasonable, and the charm of the Japanese decor was fun.  Anime playing on the TV!  Manga to read on the shelves!  Seems like a great place to eat & hang out!  Oishi!!

WzGXrm_HH8tKfAs6nfk_aw.text: My boyfriend and I like coming here because there are a scarce amount of udon places in vegas, sadly! Cafe Sanuki offers more than udon, but offers a cool Japanese cafeteria experience.   The first time we came here, we ordered the curry and cold udon, which were good but wasn't quite the Japanese curry that we were looking for! But we decided to give this place a second chance because it seemed to more about the udon than the curry, and we were right!   This time I ordered the niku udon and my boyfriend ordered the kake udon, and shared a side of gyoza. Good choice! The beef udon was full of flavor! Could have used a little bit larger pieces of beef but the flavor was on point and the amount of noodles given for me was plenty.   The gyoza was a nice touch as a side and completed the meal. They had a nice crisp and the flavor from the sauce made it that much better.   At checkout we were pleasantly surprised that with checking in on yelp, we got a free drink. Which was pleasant because of the Calpico machine they had available as well as their Sanuki lemonade! TIP: mix them both together, you will be pleasantly surprised!  This place is great for a Japanese fix, something not too heavy and not too fancy. Will be back here again!

FxWEU1PRrZwrTmneYIGo-w.text: Not feeling like eating Ramen my girl and I defaulted to our usual Udon place Cafe Sanuki. Cafe Sanuki is one of our usual haunts if we're around Spring Mountain since they offer a good variety of delicious Udon bowls. Parking is pretty easy to get and seating is always pretty plentiful. Immediately as you enter through the doors there is a big glass display of the various Udon bowls, curry and rice dishes they provide recreated in colorful plastic. The food looks semi-realistic like a frozen Hans Solo in carbonite. There's also Japanese pop music playing over the speakers. The ordering process is very cafeteria-esque in that you grab a tray and tell the staff what main dish you want and they prepare it for you behind the counter. There's a couple of large televisions screens that have photos with associated numbers so you can order by number if you can't read or write like me. Further along in the counter line there is also a fried food station that offers a variety of tempura items (shrimp, white fish, veggies, etc) and some onigiri. Toward the end is the cashier where you pay for the items you ordered and add a drink option. Cafe Sanuki doesn't offer any desserts, but there are plenty of other places around you can get your sweet tooth on. After paying you find a seat and start eating, however if whatever you ordered takes a bit longer to prepare someone from the staff will deliver to you at your table. Here's what we ordered and what we thought: -Carbonara - This is Udon with a white cream sauce and little pieces of pork scattered throughout. It was delicious and what I usually order. The flavor was good and the pork belly pieces were very tasty. Order this unless you want a more watery broth. -Kake Udon (added one egg) - This is the most basic Udon bowl. Noodles were large and soft, fish cake was standard issue, broth was clear and tasted fine. Get this for a no nonsense bowl of Udon. -Mini Curry Rice Bowl - This is a pretty basic rice bowl with curry, ginger and green onions. If you order the actual Curry Bowl then there will be some pork tonkatsu pieces included. However we ordered this in order to try the curry flavor and it wasn't bad. Order this if you need an extra item to fill your belly similar to how fries are a side dish to fill you up if your burger just isn't enough OR remember how Jek Porkins is taken out so quickly in Star Wars A New Hope without really contributing to the rebellion's fight. I mean he probably helped by drawing fire and heat from the Death Star guns to allow the other guys like Luke to have an easier time, but really he wasn't necessary. So yeah, treat the Mini Curry Bowl in terms of usefulness like Jek Porkins. Get or skip. Probably skip. -Shrimp Tempura - This was delicious. The tempura wasn't too oily the shrimp size was large and the crunch was satisfying. Satisfying like seeing Princess Leia strangle Jabba with her slave chain. Get this unless you don't like shrimp or loved Jabba. If you liked Jabba then you have issues. -Tempura Fish Cake - The fish cake is large and like the shrimp the tempura was fried well. This was good. Get this if you like fish cake. -Chicken Karaage - This wasn't that great. The chicken pieces were large and although the seasoning was fine, the chicken to surface area ratio of the chicken wasn't favorable. Skip this. -Pumpkin Tempura - This was good, crispy, and it had the nice starchy flavor/texture that only comes from a gourd. Take this or leave it depending on whether you like pumpkin. Overall Cafe Sanuki is definitely worth a visit to get some Udon. The prices are reasonable, seating is plentiful, and the music is Japanese and not the music from the Star Wars cantina. youtu.be/a55z9NJEN1s P.S. I apologize for making too many Star Wars references.

gP21AT5vDEGKF4PiumImwA.text: We've tried really good udon, from Tokyo to those hidden gem noodle houses in LA & Torrance, CA and I have to say Cafe Sanuki's is on par. The ordering system is cafeteria style where you walk in, get a tray and pick your dishes or order them at the counter if it isn't there. I've been wanting to try their Carbonara Udon after seeing it on their Instagram page and I wasn't disappointed. The Carbonara sauce (not just a dressed up Alfredo) was authentic-tasting, right down to the generous sprinkling of hand-cut bacon chunks--yes, chunks, not those commercialized dried bacon bits found in shakers. My wife opted for the more traditional Niku Beef Udon which boasts Sanuki's rich and flavorful signature broth topped with green onions, tender marinated beef and thick and soft udon! Cafe Sanuki's price is also on point, which is why we also tried a few side dishes like their Takoyaki and Pork Belly Bao. There's more on the menu we'd love to try so it's a safe bet to say we'll be back. We're just happy there's finally a good udon shop here in Las Vegas (and the only one we know of that offers the Zaru/Zuru Udon!

SSMyFuct3Uq2jxp978biuA.text: While my friends and I have had Cafe Sanuki on our list of places to try for quite some time, I have to admit they've never really been a priority for us. Instead, we ended up making our way to spots like Shang Artisan Noodles, Pho Kim Long, and Monta Ramen. However, after Udon Monzo shuttered, you can bet Cafe Sanuki moved to the top. Not to say that the two are related, but considering how Udon Monzo folded despite their awesome reviews (and udon, presumably), we weren't going to take a chance these guys might end up shuttering on us as well! Fashioned with the same cafeteria-style set-up as Marukame Udon in Hawaii, Cafe Sanuki had me feeling all kinds of excited as soon as we walked inside. The wealth of open seats and lack of a line didn't hurt (we got here about 45 mins before closing and were starving), but their menu looked pretty legit (and not just because I was hungry). Nearly two dozen varieties of udon (in soup or sauce, hot or cold), rice bowls/plates, and an array of sides (assorted types of tempura, gyoza, baos, onigiri, etc.). -- NIKU BEEF UDON...$7.80 -- SHRIMP TEMPURA...$1.75 -- WHITE FISH TEMPURA...$1.90 -- SWEET POTATO TEMPURA...$1.25 -- TAKOYAKI (3pcs)...$2.80 (yelp.com/biz_photos/cafe...) The udon itself was solid, and the beef wasn't bad (wish the shreds were bigger), but the broth could've been a little richer/more flavorful. As for the tempura, the sweet potato didn't do much for me, but the fish was great. Kind of weird how they don't list the type, but it was crispy and quite tasty. Lastly, much like with the shrimp tempura, the takoyaki was more or less fine - crispy on the outside, but I wish it had more octopus. -- PORK BELLY BAO...$2.95 (yelp.com/biz_photos/cafe...) Beyond being a small sample size (my friend and I split it), this wreaked of cilantro (yuck), so I'm biased. That being said, I still thought this was just okay. The slaw didn't help, but I didn't care much for the sauce and, as a whole, it felt kind of dry. -- BRAISED PORK BELLY RICE BOWL...$7.80 (yelp.com/biz_photos/cafe...) My friend over ordered, so we ended up sharing this among the entire group. So again, small sample size, but I liked this. Although a few pieces of pork weren't as juicy as others, I liked how well seasoned it was and how the shredded ginger complemented the overall flavors. Even though we weren't overwhelmed by the majority of what we had, it should be noted that we likely didn't come at the best time either. Given how we arrived within an hour of them closing, I imagine some of their stuff might be sitting out (tempura) and/or the last of what was left (pork belly?). Had we come during their peak dinner service, for example, I'm sure stuff would've been hot/moist since turnover would've been higher. All in all, while I can't say my experience here was as glowing as it was for so many others, it wasn't all that shabby either. The udon is terrific and there are numerous varieties to choose from. What's more, prices here are super reasonable (either that or I'm just that jaded by Bay Area prices). Cafe Sanuki may not be nearly as good as Marukame Udon in Hawaii, but they're better than the last couple of udon joints I've tried in SF. Given all the love they've received, I'll definitely be back to give them another shot, try more of their udon, and to see how much better it really is to come earlier in the day/evening rather than right before closing. THREE AND A HALF STARS rounded down for now.

RDQf1jklTwWz22CbpW_r7A.text: In Miami I was surrounded by affordable South American food, now in Vegas it's Asian food! I found this place on yelp and drove over. Plenty of parking available.  When you walk in there's a display or their food. You order and pay in a mini market set up on one side of the restaurant. Seating is on the other side. Very clean and well maintained establishment. Staff was very friendly. Menu was clear, pricing was clear. I got served immediately and had some questions answered.  I choose the creamy tomato seafood udon and gyoza.  I tried the teas but I'm overall not a fan of that. I did love the Calpico, something that was new to me. The food came out quick. Everything was delicious. It was not only very good but also very cheap: for the price of only $13.64 total tax included. That's amazing. I recommend!

22T14y-jHBOnRTuibwmKHQ.text: Tried the creamy tomato seafood udon.  Udon bite was chewy and delicious.  The sauce reminded me of a seafood tomato bisques - exactly what we were looking for.  Also the price is awesome and if you get a drink you can get UNLIMITED CALPICO WOW.  The service was also very very good for a cafeteria style restaurant.

Rk-YfjJSoaohfxoXvXxXrQ.text: OMG. Amazing dishes.  So so good.  If you're a NOODLE LOVER...  you have to, have to come and give this amazing spot a try. I love love love this place.   First time here and this spot will be in rotation of my regular go to spots.  First, the young lady who was at the door, she was very welcoming, sweet, helpful and attentive.   Everything on the menu looks so delicious.  #11 and #12 are their most popular.  However we went with.........  #7- Tonkatsu Shoyu #8- Spicy TANTAN  #16- Spicy Miso Pork  We also grabbed- Shrimp Tempura  Gyoza  Chicken skewer  All were amazing, we even went for seconds on  The gyoza.   The broth of the Spicy TANTAN ugggggh myyyyy gooooodesss.  Happy girl dance.. amazing, flavorful, right amount of kick, salty and yet a slight hint of sweetness.  Very filling.  Loved it.  Tonkatsu Shoyu was amazing as well, delicious broth but not my go to.  I love spice and for me personally it's just to bland but still good.  Their egg is boiled then deep fried which was different but not my fav.  Ooooooh and let's not forget the Spicy Miso Pork. That dish is fresh, spicy,  again a light sweetness.  It has a nuttiness to it that I just cannot get enough of.  That bowl had me at first slurrrrrp.    Place is very clean and organized.  We arrived at opening time 11:30am and by 12noon place was filling up.   I left a happy girl, money well spent.  Their prices are reasonable and you will not leave disappointed or hungry.   Till next time My Sanuki friends! \(^-^)  *Peep the photos
