yxz_CO1xKC5LZ92Y8ss81w.text: We found cafe Sanuki as we were hoping for a no frills fast casual place for a big group and it caught our eye in the reviews since it reminded us of maragume in Hawaii/ LA and so we came.  It's the type where you get in line and order your udon and extras.  Tempura is grab yourself style.    I always default to the cold udon because I love how chewy the cold noodles are.  Usually it is hard for udon to stay chewy in the hot broth.  The onsen  egg is also perfectly cooked.    They also have some different options that include a Chinese dish that is like Zha jiang noodles but with udon.  It was quite delicious and had a lot of good sesame flavor.  They also have beef bowls which are gooood as well.    Check in for a free drink!  Calpico fountain!!! What.

I4hYG8BzIf7d9Xq2uuS6kg.text: Cafe Sanuki is the best place to get a quick lunch or dinner, either by yourself or with friends. There's nothing fancy about food, it's good and fill up your stomach. There's no table service either. After you pay and receive the food, you have to take care everything by yourself: bring it to the table, pick your drink, pick your utensils, and clean up after yourself when you are done.  That's how they can keep the price low and focus on the food.   Cafe Sanuki doesn't offer much, but if you ever need a quick meal, this is the place to go

hRwNLabjKTObxy3DvQD3pA.text: This is probably one of my favorite Japanese restaurants in town. If you're looking to splurge, this is the place to hit up. Service is friendly and people are polite c: good for groups~

photos.caption: Photo of Cafe Sanuki - Las Vegas, NV, United States. They have a display for serving size references!! My favourite dish is the pork belly rice bowls^^
Photo of Cafe Sanuki - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Haven&#39;t been here in awhile c: more menu items!!

DNy5-5mVBM511kHo6fa4RQ.text: There is nothing more exciting than having a place reintroduce you to food that you have had many times as something new.   Cafe Sanuki, located in the city that never sleeps, has definitely created one of the most elevated Udon noodles around.   Excellent characteristics and bite on the Udon noodles with a broth that's subtle in earthy flavors, yet it's effectiveness lingers with each slurp.   Cafe Sanuki also offers Pork Belly Bao; delicate pork belly pieces inside a soft, steamed bun, with in house made slaw. It was simple and not clouded with unnatural flavors.  Tempura, rice rolls are also offered as a part of their "Munchies" menu and don't forget to order Oden ( fish cake, radish, Konjac or egg) as an addition to your Udon.   No need to be dressed to the nines for something so impressive doesn't need white table cloths. Cafe Sanuki is pure, simple dining.   "Itadakimasu".

1aRQMOPwBsQrkBxJufJUjQ.text: This is a great casual dining restaurant. The place is really open and spacious. I like how we ordered in line and they bring you the food later. I always come her and ordered the seafood tomato cream udon. It is my FAVORITE dish here. The price is good for its portion as well. I gave it a 4 star because I have tried other dishes and also the one incident where the karaage was raw. The dan dan noodle and the shoyu udon was ok. It is definitely not the best but it is good for its price. The rice curry dish was definitely my least favorite because of the sourness of the dish. I'm not sure if that's how it supposed to taste like but I would not recommend it. Beside all that, the staff is nice and friendly. If you do give this place a shot, try the seafood tomato cream udon! :)

xV5MAztRhoiG_t_AyCcWyg.text: This place super good.  Food was good but I only gave a 4 because the tempura we got from the food bar was barely warm.  Noodles are made fresh daily and that was delicious.  Overall everything was delicious.  This place reminds me a mini Mitsuwa (which hopefully we get one here in Vegas soon). The place is very roomy and you dont feel like you are eating on top of each other.  Cant wait to go back!

MGvsEb-Hm9bXP6MYl7QAVA.text: Sometimes you just crave a good comforting bowl of noodles but many of the places in Vegas don't specialize in udon, you'd usually have to go to a general Japanese restaurant which can turn into a fancier ordeal than what you wanted. What's really nice about this place is that its main focus is udon dishes from traditional soup based to modern spinoffs (such as carbonara); it's a very casual establishment where you order in almost a cafeteria-style fashion, falling in line and going straight to the register, picking up some extra pre-made appetizers along the way. There's lots to choose from on the menu with each dish costing around $8-10, with generous portions that would satisfy even the hungriest of customers. The noodles are freshly made and the difference in quality can be tasted! I've tried the cheesy carbonara and the mentai cream (a fish roe based cream sauce) and they were both delicious and satisfying! Another nice thing is that they have an array of not your run of the mill drinks, such as calpico, their specialty lemonade (a creamier mouthfeel), and a variety of brewed flavored teas. Overall I loved this place and would highly suggest it!

mDjoTaOm35KYLlNQEqEk-w.text: Me and my friends decided to leave the strip for a little and explore Chinatown! The food here was definitely affordable and the atmosphere was pleasant and there were plenty of tables for everyone! The food was pretty good, but was a little cold. Also, they messed up my friends order but did reimburse him and give him a free meal! The employees are very pleasant and I would definitely go back!

dvEZr-CZAMkGV8olJstpjQ.text: Cafeteria style Restaurant serving Japanese udon, curry, tempura and rice balls at a very affordable price.  Everything tasted pretty good, nothing to complain about...perfect for large groups and kids.

zniEQWHstqKz79q20VITZg.text: First time at the cafe. I was so hungry walking in I didn't know what to order it all looked good. I got the curry udon but I don't recommend it, it was kind of bland. I got it with a side of pork katsu and a side order of gyoza. The pork belly sandwiches are a must!! Super good and highly recommended. We also tried the beef broth udon which was really good. Plenty of seating for everyone and climate inside was awesome on a 100 degree day. For drinks if you like calpico on tap this is your spot! Great for kids and adults with plenty of options to eat for everyone!

dgBeQdKLg_x4ErhRLjWm1g.text: Calipico drink on tap is the bomb! Thank you for an amazing check in offer. Service was good and the Udon definitely tasty! Would recommend. We had the spicy udon, the creamy udon, and the seafood tomato cream. All tasty!

Upp8DkAy8eb6NMF7k1EUwg.text: If Cafe Sanuki broth and Oodle Noodle noodles married, it was be the PERFECT recipe. So happy to have tried this place because udon is certainly my noodle of choice! As soon as I walked in to Cafe Sanuki I was transported back to Japan. The furnishing, the decor, everything was exactly like udon shops in Japan! Grab a tray and start your journey :)  I ordered the Mentai noodles and the boyfie order the #1. Both were really, really good flavor wise, but the noodles were a bit too soft. Fresh udon noodles should be a little chewy like Oodle Noodle's! Still, it was really good. The shrimp and squid tempura were amongst the best I've ever had (including Japan). The onigiri's are packed with fish so it's the perfect fish/rice ratio.   Super inexpensive and a good meal. Definitely will be back!

photos.caption: Photo of Cafe Sanuki - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Cafe Sanuki - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Cafe Sanuki - Las Vegas, NV, United States

-DNntbl4U1oa12ih86dYYQ.text: Cafe Sanuki really threw me off with its ordering system. Honestly it was just awkward and a mess to me. No one wants to stand in line when they go out to eat. They do advertise as cafeteria style but I feel like it's a huge disservice to their staff for tipping and their customers.  Anyways! My favorite udon place closed down.. Monson. Tear . And Sanuki has a similar menu. The food here is like a 6.5 out of 10 to me. Just at the right level to warrant eating out because you can't make it at home conveniently.   They have a digital menu while you wait of mostly udon dishes and a couple of rice dishes. They also have some appetizers like their bao buns and their tempura station which is already made and a la carte.   I love how they have a couple traditional Italian pasta dishes that they Japanese udon-ified like the carbonara and the seafood dish. The seafood dish had a decent amount of seafood for the price. I also really liked their curry bowl.  I had no idea the service style was like this and it's actually a lot of back and forth between the customer and the staff. Some things you order and take right away while other things get brought out to you or you go pick up.  With that aside the food is actually pretty tasty and satisfying. I couldn't give them a higher rating because nothing really warrants it. The service was nothing special and the food although solid for a casual dining place it is not anything I crave and nothing was a stand out.

Photo of Cafe Sanuki - Las Vegas, NV, United States

_gXFwM051M3XJ7yJ6uGjDw.text: Just came back from vacation in Honolulu where Marukame sets the udon standard, now in Vegas where we stumbled at Cafe Sanuki. Udon and broth, tempuras were really tasty and good! Checking for free drinks, not Marukame but will satisfy your udon cravings nonetheless!

KeqLbKZf-PNpKPecOXWlcg.text: The most authentic noodle shop in Vegas!  I'd say this place had the most overall authentic experience to what we had in Tokyo. Granted, there are a lot of Westernized dishes (udon carbonara?) but overall I was quite impressed.  Just part the plastic menu items, you order noodles or rice dishes and then pick up various tempura vegetables and meats and then pay at the end of the line.  I had the tonkotsu shoyu udon, it was delicious. The meat was smoky and well cooked, the broth not too salty and very flavorful. Noodles were cooked well and not soggy or too chewy. Very good texture.  Also tried the shishito peppers, tempura shrimp and the chicken karaage. I enjoyed them all and appreciated that the staff cooked some chicken fresh. I also like that you can just grab them a la carte, and the prices were very reasonable.  To top it off, they've got Calpico drink, still not sure what it really is but made it feel much more authentic.   Definitely plan to return.

FtUf5zzKKWI2JnZpgrCs4A.text: Cafe Sanuki was the best way I could have thought of ending my most recent Vegas trip. I had never heard of this cute little shop so I wasn't sure what to expect, but the photos had me salivating! I wasn't prepared for the entirety of its deliciousness.  I ordered the mentai cream udon while my guy ordered the carbonara udon (totally not because I kept saying how much I wanted both :^)). Both were deliciously creamy without giving me that heavy, overkill fatty feeling. The portions were also perfect. The mentai is definitely the lighter of the two, but I thought both of them were indescribably yummy and I highly recommend them. The miso pork belly bowl we added on to share was good, but nothing special and I probably wouldn't order it again. I would also pass on the onigiri as you can get these from any Japanese market for cheaper.   One of my favorite things about this place is the fact that, if you go onto yelp, you have the option to get 10% off your bill or check in for a free drink (unlimited refills at the self serve drink bar). I suggest getting the drink if you're dining in because it's soo worth it. They have original calpico in the dispensers so you can drink as much of this as your heart desires. They also have other cool drinks like homemade blood orange tea, as well as your typical soda machines. The best part is that they have flavored syrup pumps at your disposal if you're feeling adventurous and want to try mixing your own concoction.  As a tip for newbies like myself, Cafe Sanuki is cafeteria style. Upon walking in, you may be confused but the layout is pretty simple. Decide what you want and order with the cooks--while you wait for your meal, you have the option to pick up some tempura, etc from their hot bar. After this, you pay at the cashiers. That's it. Enjoy!!!

vt5t7AwOisnBuJibGgq8NQ.text: I came here because I was really craving udon and Cafe Sanuki did not disappoint. I got the curry udon which was so rich and flavorful. My bf got the beef udon which reminded me a lot of sukiyaki, it was very yummy. This restaurant is so interesting and unique in that the way you order is cafeteria style where you get a tray and they serve you your udon at the counter. It was very cool to experience because I had never seen anything like that before and it makes me wonder if restaurants in Japan are like this?   The staff here is so friendly and made us feel very welcome. I want to come back to try other things!

Wp-b4csD3-NfgCwwQQmOLg.text: Reminds me of Japan. The service is great and the food is wonderful. I had the nabayaki udon. It was a generous serving that had lots of goodies in it. I also had a kragi stick that was delicious...so was the tonkatsu curry.  Perfect on a cold winter's day or for Japanese comfort food.

KOHKL7iSKazNybVO6QgKlg.text: I really like Cafe Sanuki, their udon was super affordable and delicious! The noodles are perfectly cooked, and the broth very flavorful.   Ordered the Nabiaki Udon bowl with a mini rice bowl option for only $3.95 more! The Nabiaki comes out piping hot, and with many toppings. It is super HUGE and you definitely will not leave hungry. I would recommend not getting the mini rice bowl option unless you're sharing with another person or super hungry.  Definitely coming back to try more dishes.

OGPxEbzj5pnGRPcDluX_rw.text: HOLY UDON! I am OBSESSED with this place & their udon. When you enter, they have an adorable display of the types of udon they have and what they each entail. They have a large dining room which is great because at that time I came with a party of 8 people plus 2 babies (my twins) for my Auntie's birthday dinner.   I tried their kake udon which is basically traditional Japanese udon. Yes, I know I'm boring when I could've gotten something more interesting like Mentai Cream Udon... BUT I judge an udon place based on the original udon! I added just shrimp tempura and fish cake on top cos I believe those two + udon are a perfect trio to the palate! I was BLOWN AWAY at how delicious it was! It wasn't too salty or too much of anything. I literally could've gone for seconds if I didn't have my twins with me, lol. They also have all-you-can-drink CALPICO! Y'all... I love Calpico! It's supposedly good for you? Even if it that's not True, let me believe that it is anyway lol.   Anyway, I am definitely going to eat here more often and recommend this place to others! It's a definite MUST TRY udon place if you're ever around the area!

qKSZYvDCCACQzhLaH2XVXA.text: This is a great place to get Japanese food!  It reminds me of udon restaurants in Tokyo.  They specialize in a variety of udon dishes and both the nabiaki and niku beef udons were delicious.  The curry rice dish is also very good!  I'm often disappointed in Japanese curry served in many restaurants because it tastes like what I make at home (S&B Golden Curry) but the curry here did not taste like that.  It reminded me of some of the curry served in Tokyo!

rIvwnS7nYDCRFRXlsSE5BQ.text: 5 stars for the atmosphere, 3.5 stars for the food. Curry udon is a bit different from your normal Japanese curry taste, maybe a bit sweeter. Did get the fish roe udon - the broth was excellent and not overpowering, although I'm not sure that udon is the right kind of noodle to pair it with. Definitely had a Japan cafe feel and was a nice place to sit and relax for a quick and convenient evening dinner.

S5tne6ivn8Rs0Ja0uC8akQ.text: It was our first time here. If you tell them it's your first visit, they all shout something.  Customer service was excellent.  My husband liked his curry udon, and I liked my mentai cream udon. The kitsune udon was just ok.   We got the combo and added a small bowl of rice. It was tasty. We left with full stomachs. It was really affordable, too!  Great choice for picky kids!

SICqLxTFUTLH1HUGj0g6mA.text: Came on a Friday night and was skeptical when there were practically no other patrons in the restaurant. The menu and cafeteria style is reminiscent of Marugame Udon, but with more variety.   The prices are very reasonable - I got a niku (beef) udon and was full off less than $10, and that's including tax and tip! I ate it all and drank every last drop of the broth. Quality was very good, definitely hit the spot. The restaurant staff are genuinely friendly and very nice.

RIeMNnP6h-P91Do_0nSzfg.text: I will need to come see this place again I got the curry udon, it wasn't that good. If you want good curry udon go to Curry Zen.  The inside is big and nice I really like it, the service there was really nice too lol the girl who gave me my curry noodle sang to me. Everyone there seems to love working there which is a nice thing. The bowls there are huge! And if you check in on yelp you'll get a free drink. It isn't expensive at all. I will come back again my next visit maybe and give it another try and hopefully update it to a better review. Oh I love their straws!!! lol

2YNRSf0DKmJIePyX6gV5og.text: We've started going off the strip when spending time in vegas. Cafe Sanuki is one of the restaurants we found on Yelp and tried.   Portion sizes here are HUGE!!! we ordered 3 items between 2 people because we're pigs and SF sizes tend to be small. HUGE mistake. we left completely stuffed! We could've shared one item between the 2 of us.   The food here is not the highest quality japanese food you'd fine, but the value for what you get is excellent. We tried the curry udon, curry katsu (fried pork over rice) and soft boiled egg udon. I wouldn't recommend the egg udon as it was a cold udon but the currys were very tasty! get the katsu curry if you like or the curry udon if you like noodles. They're essentially the same thing

RTVhCIwNoRib28Q6Ly5sdw.text: SO GOOD!!! If I were to rate this place out of 10 they would be 100. Everything about this place is amazing!! The ambience. The servers. The food. The drinks!  Ambience- Reminds me of japan! Made me miss japan sooo much. The wooden furniture, lighting, and the way you choose your food. The way you choose your food is like at the train stations in japan! They even have the fake plastic foods that look exactly like their dishes!! So Cute. You get in line and pick and choose what you want and pay at the register.   Servers- The nicest servers I've ever met. They're so sweet and nice! They're honestly the best?!?!?! All so friendly and welcoming!  Food -  Absolutely delicious. Ordered the #11 - sauted sweet cream tomato udon, 8 shrimp tempura, 1 sweet potato tempura, 1 curry udon, 1 steak and rice plate, 2 kake udon, 1 tonkatsu udon, 1 takoyaki, 1 pork belly rice bowl, 2 pork buns, and 1 salmon onigiri all for $80ish dollars!!   Sweet cream tomato udon was the best. I shouldn't have worn a white shirt though don't use chopsticks when eating this dish! But it was delicious!! Better than spaghetti tbh. The udon noodles with the sauce is so good.  Curry, kake, & tonkatsu udon was good too!  The steak and rice plate threw my family off guard because there was gravy. They just thought it was just seared steak.   Tempura was good! Their tempura sauce is on the side near the beverages so you have to get it there. You can also sprinkle matcha salt into your tempura!! I love that so much! Definitely adds depth in flavor.   The pork belly bowl reminded me of yoshinoya beef bowl! Still good regardless.  The pork belly buns were big in portion and definitely worth my $$$.   Didn't get to eat the salmon onigiri yet bc we saved it as a snack for later...  You get free drinks when you check in on yelp!! They allow every person in your party check in and get a free drink even when you're paying all together!!   Will definitely come back in the future for their food esp the sweet cream tomato udon....

SIJxICltNn_PZYSEDMfQSA.text: Delicious food, nice workers, come here often. It started getting busy now but great for business

63kHQ8oXFgELtnIElbhcGg.text: Yes yes yes! Great udon with lots of unique flavor options (carbonara? Hey, someone will want that im sure...not me, but someone!)   We came here for the first time today for dinner and immediately loved the authentic details. You're greeted by plastic versions of all the entrees - just like in Japan, which is such a smart way to figure out your order. The patrons slurping their noodles and speaking Japanese in the dining area sealed the deal and we knew this place was legit! The atmosphere is classy fast casual, so you order at the counter and then take a seat in the hip dining room area lined with Japanese books and trinkets. They have a ton of tempura options to accompany your udon noodles - the fish cake and shrimp were both out of this world! I will be working my way through their tempura list now! I got the house udon (sesame and miso with ground pork) and it was so flavorful. Portions are large and I brought home enough for a second meal! Prices are totally reasonable too! We got two udon dishes and three tempuras and spent around $25. Cant wait to come back!!!

cus42FTVAkvqGCTMj3g6Gw.text: This is a nice restaurant setting but a little confusing when you walk in cause you don't see right away where you order. The noodles here are good and the noodle portion size is big. They advertise a deal to get a mini size of their rice bowls and we got the chicken curry katsu mini size. You'd expect to get some chicken katsu in it since it's a mini size right? Wrong, you don't get any chicken in it and have to pay $3 extra for chicken. Kind of deceiving if your picture has chicken katsu in it. When we asked the girl taking our order about it she got a little rude. So we ended up getting the chicken karaage from the side area instead and it was super cold. May or may not return again, slightly disappointing first experience.

photos.caption: Photo of Cafe Sanuki - Las Vegas, NV, United States

bW27FXvg-D_OaP04PjkjMA.text: I've been to Cafe Sanuki a number of times, having tried the different types of products they serve. The process of ordering food is that of a cafeteria, something I have not experienced since grade school. One can observe the menu, a majority of the selection being udon and rice dishes. The staff is there nicely help one along the process.  My first time actually here I had ordered the Carbonara udon, an absolutely filling bowl of white sauce udon. Still good though, but was just more than I could handle which fortunately justifies the price. My second go here I decided to try out the rice bowls, specifically the Braised House Pork Bowl. It was a lovely amalgamation of pork, egg, red radish, green onion, and rice. I had ordered the mini sized version which seemed to be the prefect size for myself. Lastly, my latest outing I had ordered something a bit unorthodox here, the Pork Belly Bao. The pork belly bao is my favorite thing here. It is both inexpensive and savory, the soft neutral bao bun works perfectly to enhance the flavor of the cooked pork belly. Every bite down to its last is just my personal little heaven. The drink selection I also would like to give a shout out. The house lemonade is uniquely different than typical lemonade, so much so that I would really recommend serving yourself some. Cafe Sanuki has become one my favorite spots in Spring Mtn., it being both an atypical restaurant/cafeteria hybrid, and just serving all-around great food with great service. Check it out!

photos.caption: Photo of Cafe Sanuki - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Pork Belly Bao Price: $3.00 as of 08/12/18
Photo of Cafe Sanuki - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Carbonara Udon Price: $8.80 as of 08/12/18

07Qo5iPhJzciH8xzeCgV8Q.text: The server brought the food to our table and they even clean up for us we got our  drinks for free and there were free refills.The food was good and delicious..

Kvess42rvxyCZ7euQlViRw.text: Here is my doodle about the oodles of noodles :]  Before anything else, let me just say that this place straight up reminds me of Shirokiya in Hawaii. Every time I go back home to the islands, I always hit up that place that is located in Ala Moana Center. And now, a part of it has magically warped into Las Vegas!  As soon as you enter, you will see a display case of everything they have on the menu. It gives the names of all the menu items and little descriptions of what each one is. It is like a lil udon museum. So cheesy, I know. :p  Pricing is not bad at all and seems to be about the same as other places. Maybe even cheaper, but worth it. This gives you a chance to try other menu items, since the portions are not overwhelming.  The restaurant has a walk-up line where you order and pick up your food. Just like a cafeteria, you get a tray, order, and wait for your food to be prepared before making a final stop at the cash register to pay. After your main dishes are prepared, you will come across a small section of add-on items. Some of these items include a variety of tempura, chicken skewers, soft boiled eggs, and spam musubi. After all that, seating is your choice. This restaurant is pretty sizable and there are plenty of tables and chairs throughout.  Now for my fave menu items and recommendations. I have tried the Kitsune Udon, Seafood Tomato Cream, Mentai Cream Udon, and the Beef Rice. As for add-ons, I've tried the shrimp/squid tempura, chicken skewers, and spam musubi. I highly recommend the Mentai Cream Udon. It had just the right amount of flavor, wasn't too salty, and it was just delicious. The broth and noodles of the Kitsune was just as good, so I'm pretty sure the flavors of the rest would be too. There was nothing special about the Beef Rice, but it was a nice little add-on. Plus, you can order the rice dishes in mini or regular sized bowls. A great option when wanting to try several different menu items.  All in all, this place is really great to hit up when you want a quick and simple meal. Udon is comfort food and there's nothing more satisfying than a bowl of noodle soup when the craving for something hot and soothing is just too real. lol If you're in the area, make the stop! :]

WsedRa3--5iFB_-X8kmZJw.text: Cannot go wrong with this place if you are looking for good quality Japanese food. I really enjoyed their mentai cream udon was very tasty. I also ordered the spicy udon and although it wasn't very spicy, it was tasty. Good place to try if you are looking for something like this in the Vegas area.

PuDCEd4rzTsFlHNUhroFLg.text: First time here. We will definitely come back here everytime we will be here in Las Vegas. Good food with good price nd service too...

hxXEqiMoIYEmJDrL-BWKsw.text: The udon was pretty spot on... enjoyed it. Taste was pretty comparable. I would definitely come and have the udon here again. Love the calpico drink fountain and the lemonade was very much like the Japanese lemonade. Unfortunately, that's where it would stop.   My disappointment was the gyoza... what was in it?!?! It was the saltiest, flavorless and not good at all. I think my dad who's not a great cook makes better ones. And the fried chicken... not that good either. Our food has a specific flavor with some Variation. But when you eat something that makes you go, this is not Japanese. There's something wrong.   I do commend the owner for going to Japan and learning how to make our udon but maybe some work on the sides. It was pretty inedible. My little one didn't even like it and she loves gyoza.

uAZjZslQGGtRfDU28cGvgw.text: This is definitely our to go restaurant whenever we are at Vegas!!! This place is affordable, fast, clean and fuss free, full of comfort food. There's always something for my family of 6 to eat.? I love how their tempura are always freshly fried. Their Katsu Curry rice is really delicious. The curry given is a generous portion, the pork is beautifully fried with a nice crunch n not dry at all. All in all we have tried almost every item on the menu and nothing is ever too disappointing. The staff are friendly too. Do give this place a trif you are down at Vegas.

Bf3BCHUop0Enie4_wxD_NQ.text: This place is a joke, it's boring what they describe it like to be. Very un organized they moves us 2 times...   We asked for a table of 5 and were moved 2 times, we don't appreciate this. Because of this our food was late..

xJyMVj_OjjC7_7qf0W1Gmw.text: One of my favorite Udon places in Waikiki and this place reminds me of it.   I try and eat here every time I am in Vegas and it satisfies my cravings to fly to Hawaii and get some Udon.  One of the unique things about this place is the Calpico fountain... so cool!

KBEvJM4PWVnMhqlshiQVDQ.text: Great place for a quick meal with its cafeteria-style order and pay set-up. If you like visuals before deciding what to order, this place is for you! In addition to a display case featuring models of each dish, there are full-color printed menus and screens before you order. I tried the #7  ontama bukake. The udon is served warm with green onions, tempura crispies, and a poached egg. The concentrated broth is served on the side. You also get a small bowl of soup with it. It was a good dish that sticks to the basics. I tried a fried chicken skewer--it was well seasoned, but cold. I wish they made it to order.  The onogiri is wrapped so the seaweed doesn't come into contact with the rice until you open it, so the seaweed stays crispy. The konjack reminded me of sea cucumber--kind of a crunchy rubbery texture.  There is a TV, but it was not on and there was no music, so it was pretty quiet in there.  Unfortunately the tea station was out of order, but the Calpico and lemonade make a good mix. Their straws have a uniquely large bendy section, which is fun!

photos.caption: Photo of Cafe Sanuki - Las Vegas, NV, United States

3XP9hBktLwUf_82JulybIQ.text: Not a bad place to visit if you like udon .  The price is reasonable and when you do the combo( the mini rice bowl is only $2.50) They are also promoting Yelp and a sign in will get you a free Large drink another plus ! :)   The food is decent with big portions. I would go back and recommend my friends

dtUjuEJq9SWX700YkJjWDQ.text: Disappointed. I was very excited to try this place with my mom and my sister. In the pictures, it looked so nice. In person... disappointing. It didn't even have the feel of a cafe. It felt like a cafeteria with teenager staff (who are mostly too disinterested in doing their job well: no one bothered to add utensils in the utensil area (are people supposed to eat with their hands?), you had to flag someone (really hard) to get a spoon to use for your soup, if you had a question... you had to ask this snobby cashier guy who acted like you shouldn't bother him, etc. It just wasn't the kind of experience I thought we would have, looking at these online pictures.   The food... I thought it was pretty yummy. I loved their drink selections. I love that they have all you can drink calpico!!! I love the selection of fried food that you can add with your order. I'm just not sure about the service. It just felt so... lacking. Quite different from other Japanese restos I've eaten at. This kind of service is something I would expect in a local cafeteria joint... not something like this place.   Would I come back? Probably. But, just for a quick meal. I wouldn't go here for family gatherings, date, formal work lunch, etc. Think of it like a fast food place but with better food selection.

ZlWnWsI_8cSpDc4tlvZPoQ.text: After dining here a few more times I'm sad to feel that it's a fun concept, but ultimately the quality of the udon isn't as good as many other places nearby. A good assortment of side dishes (tempura, taiyaki, rice balls), but again, unfortunately, the flavor doesn't feel like it's quite there. You'll likely have a reasonably-priced, but somewhat bland meal here.

ijz95jl7ZSeLMz_cPh4WJw.text: Fantastic. From a person that's been to Asia a few times. Doesn't always get the food. But a foodie at heart. We ordered a bunch of things. Nothing I tried I didn't like. Wild combinations I wouldn't order on my own done for you.  You won't be sorry if you visit this spot. I wish it had wait staff but the food makes up for it. This will be on my list - it was fannnnntastic - the curry noodles and the curry Pablo chicken are really good. There is a beef one #3 or #4 - order it.

GOUyvTdu8hO0WIDEWbM2hw.text: tl;dr: It's good, but you're definitely not coming here because you want the best. "Comfort food with a slight twist." is the best description I can give you.  My theory is that eventually I'll post enough reviews where it justifies the amount of times I've checked in everywhere using Yelp (I doubt I'll get to that point, but a guy can try). Cafe Sanuki is a place that, in my mind, closest resembles what a Japanese cafeteria / diner would actually look like.   It's all mostly Japanese comfort food, with rice bowls, udon, noodles, curry, and your typical appetizers running through the menu. Don't let the vast list fool you; it's all comfort that's good to fill a stomach and make you glad you ate, but it's not going to blow your mind. The good thing about Cafe Sanuki is also what holds them back: their food is safe. You won't have a bad experience there, but the food won't blow your mind. Everything is (in my opinion) fairly priced, so it has that going for them.  So if you're looking for an amazing noodle bowl or curry, you're better off finding a place that specializes it, but if you're looking for a place to eat and want a positive experience then head over to Cafe Sanuki. The prices are fair and the food is safely enjoyable.  Their service is always top-notch, too. Can't beat good service.

Dlfj2UNMU0IyrwA65_XOkQ.text: I can't even count how many times I've been to Cafe Sanuki. I love the concept of ordering and having a self serve bar of tempura and onigiri. I've tried a couple udon here but the ones I find myself always going back to is the Mentai. The creamy udon is amazing and I seriously can't get enough. If you're craving something more soupy and light I recommend the clam udon! There's a hefty amount of clam in there and the soup is nice and clean. If you guys ever have a chance the onigiri there is also really good! Overall the service of this place and vibes are amazing!

I4R4R2JHh8rwz4u8D4s3Kg.text: Cafe Sanuki recently opened and I met with a group of friends here to try different dishes. One thing I really liked was the replica dishes they have on display for you to see what the food looks like. They also have an open kitchen so you can see the udon noodles being made fresh. Cafe Sanuki claims to make the udon with the only Yamato Udon Noodle Maker (a $40,000 machine) on the west coast. The machine makes sure every noodle is made and cut to perfection. 100% natural ingredients and authentic Sanuki Broth are used.   Vegetarian Tomato Basil ($7.80) - The sauce with noodles had really good flavor and the mushrooms in the dish were delicious. This is the perfect dish for anyone who doesn't eat meat or fish.   Miso Garlic Pork Belly ($3.95 for mini size) - The pork belly had great flavor and I recommend it, but my rice was one big cold clump. I was hoping for some yummy garlicky juices to be on the rice.   Kamatama Udon ($6.45) - The udon noodles come in a bowl with freshly grated ginger and a raw egg yolk. You break the yolk and stir it in the noodles and then mix in the provided soy sauce and or condiments. I didn't expect to like this honestly and was really surprised at how much good flavor there was.   Beef Rice ($3.95 for mini size) - The beef had good flavor, but again with a cold clump of rice. Maybe they have got some kinks to work out on the rice bowls.   Niku ($7.45) - The beef, noodles and broth all had good flavor. I really liked the noodles here and this particular dish is perfect on a cold night.   They have a good variety of tempura and rice rolls. The fried zucchini is huge and delicious. For drinks they have a Freestyle Machine, fresh brewed fruit teas and their own special recipe blend lemonade. The prices and portions are fair. This place is definitely worth checking out.

It is setup cafeteria style and you choose what type of noodles you want and can add additional accessories like egg and fish cake to your soup. I got the Niku (beef) udon noodle with egg and fish cake. The broth was SO good! Really flavorful AND this place says they make the broth with NO MSG! Yay! Noodles were also just right. Not too soft, not too firm. Will definitely come back again!

ESq4Ttf1wQaPiC5V52Aawg.text: *   As a native of Japan, I was looking forward to visiting this new Udon restaurant. Overall, they're serving pretty authentic Sanuki Udon, however my first impression was the soup is too cowardly. It should be served very hot and even the soup stock could be much lighter brown by using more Dashi and mirin.  That's how the authentic Sanuki Udon Soup used in Western Japan should be.  Also I thought the Cashier is the key for the entire operation. Although all of my order were serviced at each kitchen section within a minutes, I had to wait to check-out for 5 mins. It doesn't make sense as Udon restaurant to make customer wait for so long. We, as customers want to enjoy freshly made noodles and soup right away.  I'd like to visit there again to see how their operation made progress. When I visited there, kitchen staff were still in training, and it looked only a manager knows how each section runs in the kitchen. Obviously all cooks need more time for cross training in order to make them flexibly workable at any sections.  Especially Tempura deep fryer should be kept clean. I'm sure it's not that easy to maintain the deep fryer equipment as using lots of flour & oil.  However, if the restaurant firmly wants to keep the "open kitchen concept", each cook should stay on top on cleanness and maintaining equipments. I saw there're lots of rooms to grow the business in this town.  Therefore I appreciate the owner bringing in the beautiful Udon culture to this town.   1.  2. 5 3.

JGEzC2GYN0pyepdImfV7Pg.text: Delicious Japanese food. The Katsu Curry Rice was great. My wife loved her Karage and Pork Buns. The customer service was great as we were welcomed at the door by Rich.  The food was served in big bowls. They even have bendy straws for you drink!

_IOpB1GbD4joimWSky01Yg.text: As a college student, I am painfully aware of the intersection of price and flavor. Thankfully, Chinatown never fails to deliver cheap, filling food packed with flavor, and Sanuki is no exception. There's more than a dozen inventive styles of udon to try. I ate the curry udon, and though the broth was thin, the flavors held fast to the hand pulled noodles. The cafe operates in a lunch line, which limits the throughput of guests, but adds a casual atmosphere and lets you see what you're buying. Though Sanuki is a noodle bar, don't forget to pick up the tempura and onigiri. The chefs have a great understanding on how to fry something perfectly (without bumping up your cholesterol). The rice bowls are delightful, and the portion is large. The regular bowl is the size of an entree, and 8 bucks isn't bad for the quality. Make sure to check in to get a free drink. You'll definitely want to spend it on the delicious teas and lemonades. There's no desert, but you'll be stuffed to the gills and happy as a clam for a little under 20 bucks.

mqKyNV5ywj5NHdLPMFCWxg.text: The food is not the issue why I'm writing this post and I'm always trying to give a new business slack - been here several times since opened.  Me & my daughters pretty much order the same thing each time we come here, of course with everyone picking on each other dishes.  The very last time we came here, we walked in a little after 5:00 p.m. and we saw other customers with menus sitting down so we thought they were opened and we stood at the front for a few minutes wondering why no one acknowledged us as they were workers all around and normally we're greeted at the front door which is not a big deal if they did or not, we just decided to go over to the side where we order, noticed the menu boards were off so we grab our trays and walked over to the person that takes our order, and quickly my daughter saw the asian worker kissing one of the workers there, then the guys who was kissing the co-worker was a bit confused for a moment as we were trying to order, another worker who was filling the drinks came over and said to us they were closed, they don't open until 5:30 pm, so we decided to wait and as we sat there as I watched this worker refill the drinks I saw country time lemonade powder and thought don't they claim they have homemade lemonades and checked and it says houseblend.  Oh boy.  When it finally hit 5:30 pm we ordered quite a bit however we noticed that there was a special that said if we ordered any Udon soup we can order a mini rice bowl for $3.99, so we orded this to, however when we said we would like to get the Teriyaki steak, we were told that there were only three options we could get this special for, I asked why we couldn't get this, was advised because Teriyaki Steak already came with rice, this explanation was so confusing because all the requirements to get a mini bowl was to order an Undo, now understand this, we ordered Nabiaki Udon, Spicy Tan Tan, Mentai Cream, and Yes a regular Teriaki Steak, along with a squid and sweet potatoe tempura, tuna mayo and spam rice roll, 2 orders of dumplings which I asked if they had anymore as there weren't any out, was advised they cook to order which took awhile and felt they were items we could have ate while waiting for our main meal instead they were brought out to us when our meals were done, well with all this being said I'm sure I may come back just not now because for me when I eat out I would like to just have a nice comfortable experience, unfortunately I was truly discouraged, I may return at a later time, this us not to discourage anyone as the food is decent and I really like the Mentai Cream, posting in hopes they take a look at some of what I dealt with and maybe change a few things.

eOA4_2RbCqspOMswUokcJw.text: Food is pretty good but the REAL party is their bendy straws. Would come again just for the straws.

i48Qc1liJD5pjUsR67zCGQ.text: They do so much Facebook and online advertising lately that is likely just masking their failure as a restaurant. Their restaurant is more and more empty, which only means that their tempura is just sitting under the heat lamp and getting old. The shrimp tempura and chicken I had was lukewarm, and they changed their recipe to their katsu curry rice and the breading just fell right off , curry just tasted bland. QBaB3v7vz7B2jqS9iuGaYQ.text: Visiting from CA and discovered this place from Yelp. This spot is a GREAT choice if you want simple, affordable, quality, delicious Japanese noodles AWAY from the strip.  Food is so tasty! I ordered #2, pork belly bao, and mother ordered the clam udon bowl. Portions are plenty for its pricing, just sucks we couldn't take our leftovers since we had plans afterwards.  Staff is incredibly sweet and energetic, very welcoming from the moment we entered. Though there is no waiter service, one of the cooks still checked up on our table to see if everything was good. From my observance of about 8 or so small walk-ins that night, staff ran orders out quickly, cashier (young lady) was super sweet & helpful, and customers left happy.  The inside decor is simple, yet so dynamic because of the awesome lamps! Plenty of seating as well.   One minor issue is the beeping of the buzzers they hand you for your food. If there are a lot of parties, beepings go off when food is ready for pick up. Again, minor issue (plus they had Seinfeld on TV so who cares).  Other than that- PLEASANT experience and am extremely happy I found this place to be part of our Vegas stay. Will come back when I can!

qDNL3tY5fv9lMj8I1sHrDw.text: Actual rating: 3.0 Service: friendly Price range: $-$$ Ordered: Udon: It had a good taste to it, not bland and nothing special                 Shrimp Tempura: nice and crispy, just your normal shrimp                  tempura Specialty: All Udon Revisit: Yes, if my kids are in the mood for Udon. Parking: Plenty and Free Lounge Cleanliness: clean  Overall: It brought back memories and felt like I was in back in school cafeteria.You pick up a tray and go down the aisle and pick out your food, then pay for it at the end of the counter.  It's a good place to eat and go.   If you thought that was helpful then please hit those buttons below and Happy Eating!

1LTluYn9cGHqSCqSltSY-g.text: Food was decent, perhaps a bit bland but definitely worth visiting if in the area. Service was speedy and friendly! We have tried a few dishes and likely visit again to to try a few more. The lemonade station was interesting as it offers many flavors as well as other delicious drinks.

qWJVp376eykHc5ywTY1tsg.text: Let's start off by saying that this is a SOFT OPENING.   That said, the service is very friendly and once they get into a groove and hit their stride, things will be a little faster and more efficient.   The udon here is on point. Period. I had a nice soft boiled egg that was perfectly cooked.  I'd come back anytime and have udon any day.   The tempura suffered from temperature issues but was beautifully cooked. I'm sure this will change as well as they get used to their service volume and turnover on tempura.   I also had a mini beef rice bowl (gyu-don) that was really good. Now that Las Vegas no longer has a Yoshinoya, this could be a great replacement.  The atmosphere is really cool and inviting. They made great use of the space and are able to accommodate quite a few people. The J-pop playing in the restaurant is a nice touch.   I'm definitely coming back.  If nothing else, I'm happy they decided to open a place like this. I'm gonna try the oden next time...just in time for winter!

mAEQwB6HNb1z_D9Cx_6Hyg.text: I like the fact that I was completely taken back by how the restaurant actually works. At first I thought it was your regular seating by number but then the staff quickly taught me how everything works. Regular cafeteria style where you order your stuff at the counter and then pay for it. Normally I would only see this type of service through Filipino restaurants but this was a first for me with a Japanese restaurant.   As you step in the door you get greeted by their menu. They have plastic(or I do hope its plastic) versions of what they have on their menu so you can gauge just how much the servings are per dish. I've seen these types of menu showings with plenty of japanese restaurants and I think its awesome. Because most of the time you're wondering how big the servings are for each entree. This completely eliminates that question. All you have to do is pick and choose then order.   At first I looked completely clueless as I did not know what to order. I wanted a regular udon bowl with broth but didn't know what the name was. The girl who took my order ended up giving me the Chef's Special which was udon covered in chili. It totally reminds me of Zha Zhiang Mien or Jajjangmyeon which is okay but I really wanted the broth one. Which was Kake Udon when I got a chance to actually look at their menu. Completely my mistake. I didn't tell them what I wanted I just kind of spewed a word and the girl tried her best to guess what it was.   Then I ordered a rice bowl which was also confusing to the staff because they apparently have two types of pork belly bowls, the Garlic Miso, and the Braised bowl. The cashier was totally helpful with confirming what I wanted which I did get but the staff kinda judged that since I got the huge bowl of Udon that I would've settled for a mini rice bowl instead of a regular sized one. Which was okay too. I wanted a regular sized one but I guess it worked out in the end because I had room for tempura and karaage(if this doesn't tell you I'm a fatass then yes I like eating a lot).   After the whole confusion ordering what I wanted I quickly turned my eye towards the tempura section. I immediately grabbed what's left of the fish cake tempura. They were also cranking out fresh chicken karaage at that time and I just couldn't resist. I wanted the rice balls but apparently their all fresh out of it. Which tells me I need to go here as they open. Not during the middle of the day.   After all that then you get to the drinks station. They have the fancier soda machine with the touch screen but I'm not about sodas. They do have other drinks like lemonades and flavored iced teas but my go to was the chilled yogurt drink called Calpico. Pretty straightforward, get your drinks, your utensils and off to the races.   The food was good. I have no recollection or base of what good Udon is but I have to say it was pretty tasty. The Chef's special indeed tasted like Zha Zhiang Mien which was a mystery at first but the. i found out that the owner was Chinese(or at least he had a Chinese name pardon my rudeness if I assumed wrong) and it kinda made sense then and there. The Miso Pork belly was so good. I came back another day to try the Braised Pork Belly but the Miso Pork Belly is where its at. I haven't tried their Gyudon but this won't be the last time I'm visiting these guys.   The tempura. Well I can't eat shrimp but the fish cake version I had was good too. Its not a fancy restaurant so I'm not expecing anything to blow my mind but the fish cake tempuras were exactly how I imagined it to be. The chicken Karaage was kinda dry though. I was expecting a little juiciness in them but I really can't complain about it. Just wish they had an option to have a dipping sauce with a mayo base for it just to cut the dryness of the meat.   Service wise, even if it was a cafeteria style place the cooks and the rest of the staff still ask how your food is and some even carry out conversations with you. I like that they are friendly and all but I mainly just stick to my food and eat. The cleaning part is usually you the customer bringing your tray to the collecting station. They have bins to put your dishes in but the staff urges they help youinstead of you doing it. Which is cool too.   Overall I would say I really like the feel of the place. I might end up going back a few more times to try out everything on the menu. But I'm already starting to have favorites. Rest assured this won't be the last time you see me there.   On a side note though I was able to try their rice balls or onigiri when I came back a later time but my take on it is it had way too much rice versus filling. It was still good but expected more filling. Not bad but it coild use improvement.

mKs2ZLdQDXF4U_Xffwh6Gw.text: I love the udon here. There's multiple different kinds to choose from and the portions are more than generous. lJaPkk9VEoBvkGujrDq3Rg.text: I ordered the curry udon and mentai cream udon. Everything was so good that I forgot to take pictures!!! My curry udon was great but I especially liked the mentai cream.   Tip: the shrimp tempura is great when you dip it in the curry sauce   The atmosphere reminded me of a Japanese market food court, super authentic! Highly recommended :D

TeWoZ7Jbbm5r3NGXE8pFVg.text: Decided to check out Cafe Sanuki today as it's fairly new. It is cafeteria style, so you select your desired dishes and then provide payment when complete.  When we arrived everyone was super helpful in explaining the process etc.  We ordered the Curry Udon, Miso Garlic Pork and a few pieces of vegetable & shrimp tempura. The curry udon was tasty. Nice little change from the Katsu Curry that we're used to. The noodles were thick and tender and the flavor of the curry was enjoyable.  The Pork dish was a little disappointing. I was expecting decent pieces of Pork but instead it was maybe 6 pieces of glorified bacon.  The tempura was nice and the sauce complemented them nicely. We will be back!

QWLBblC1XCt5_hDbnMvtxw.text: The food was decent. Enjoyed the tempura. However the staff needs some tweaking. Both times I have been here, they have been rude and abrasive. The female associate had to lecture her coworkers each time for me. Hire more respectable workers like the Udon prepper.

FC1WWu6jwdYEuhTzOV316w.text: Cafe Sanuki reminds me of Marukame Udon in Hawaii. I loved that place when we lived in Hawaii so I was beyond thrilled when this place opened up in Vegas. It is the same concept where you buy your food and pay and eat it at your table cafeteria style. The prices are great for a family. You can get a good meal and be full for a fair price here. Also, the staff is very welcoming and helpful! We will definitely be coming back.

dAEzRutvYG84GhwqcG1FLg.text: This is my 4th visit here, and each visit the employees have performed 200% top notch customer service. My girlfriend and I came in 30 min early, and was invited to sit at a table while we wait, a lady was also kind to offer us beverages. I consider Cafe Sanuki gem in the heart of Las Vegas.

S8y20XPfDTj4wQwGAEtA8A.text: The seafood udon is delicious. Creamy tomato sauce with reasonable amount of seafood. The udon is very good.

iXwJ2XnUwVHWNjpZgD18Lg.text: Super Delicious! To vibe and atmosphere is soothing. The employees are all very welcoming and helpful

AZ37TmTSweVSkSomecbuuw.text: Came for soft opening which had a free meal due to being on guest list.  Tried the curry udon, which was served with regular base broth topped with curry, a style I've never seen before in any other place.  While it tasted good, it's not something I'll have again; too used to other places using all curry as the broth.  I'll come back to try the other offerings though, as seeing what others ordered looked interesting to eat.

photos.caption: Photo of Cafe Sanuki - Las Vegas, NV, United States

0K88XT-5IUXjKAlxesr5UA.text: Fabulous food and service. Menu is easy to decipher with photos and good explanations. Staff is happy to help with your choices. Excellent value for the money, too

-vsdVIdmOccrTfVU7hVePQ.text: Great food, prices and fast service.  We came in for the soft opening. The employees were great about answering our questions. My food came out while my boyfriend decided on tempura sides and his came out while we talked to the cashier. The niku udon was great and very filling. Will come again while on this side of town.

photos.caption: Photo of Cafe Sanuki - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Niku Udon

UOSynVF-7OL-KXipF7XAdg.text: This  is my best favorite restaurant. It is really yummy. Actually L love noodles. All kinds of noodles here I love it.

3JQLTClCPx-6gQ9Q8qtU-g.text: This place is very yummy!!! I went here for the first time today. The portions are very large. I got nabiyaki udon and wasn't able to finish it. The udon is chewy, just like the udon I used to eat as a kid! The broth is also very savory. It was a bit confusing when I first came here though. You have to order and then you'll get a receipt and buzzer. Then you have to walk up to the actual cashier to pay (I don't understand this 2 step process). Then you can find a seat and when the buzzer rings, you don't actually go up to get your food. They'll bring it to you. Regardless, it was a nice experience. I expected the restaurant to be smaller, but it's actually very spacious! Would definitely recommend!!

EQljxfIGO9Z0nsO5dHJ9fw.text: Many udon choices that are "different". Foods were all pretty tasty. Two out of the 4 items that I wanted to order were not available, but pretty impressed with the two replacement items, which meant that I would have to come back again to try out the two items that I never got to try out today. :)
